questions.text: An injury to the structure marked as 'X' in the given image would result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of the rhomboid fossa, or the floor of the fourth ventricle.

Source- BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, page128

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient of a road traffic accident developed aphasia due to brain injury. His comprehension was affected, while fluency and repetition were intact. Which of the following is also more likely to be damaged if this part of the cerebral cortex is injured?
questions.solution:
• The case with intact fluency and repetition and loss of comprehension describes Wernicke's aphasia.
  • Wernicke's area is Brodmann area 22, which is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus.
  • Heschel's gyrus, or the auditory cortex is Brodmann area number 41,42, which is located in the anterior part of the Superior temporal gyrus.
  • Thus, an injury in this gyrus can involve both these areas.
  • Sensory association area(area-5, 7) is located in superior PARIETAL gyrus.
  • Frontal eye field (area-8) is located in the middle FRONTAL gyrus.
  • Broca's area (44, 45) is located in inferior frontal gyrus. Injury here causes loss of fluency of speech.
  • The Broca's and Wernicke's areas are connected by the arcuate fasciculus and injury to it causes conduction aphasia, with loss of repetition.

Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, page135

questions.text: Which of the following is a ball and socket joint?
questions.solution:
• Incudo-malleolar is a saddle joint
  • Incudo-stapedial is a ball and socket joint

Reference: BD Chaurasia's handbook of general anatomy, 4th edition, 57

questions.text: A 24-year-old cricketer presented to the Orthopaedics OPD with pain in the shoulder joint during bowling. He was diagnosed with a rotator cuff tear. Which of the following muscles constituting the rotator cuff attaches to the lesser tubercle?
questions.solution:
The rotator cuff is constituted by Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Teres MINOR and subscapularis. They provide stability to the shoulder joint. Additionally, rotator cuff muscles help in the mobility of the shoulder joint by facilitating abduction, medial rotation, and lateral rotation.

  • Subscapularis: Medial (internal) rotation of the shoulder
  • Supraspinatus: Abduction of the arm
    • Necessary for the initial 0 to 15 degrees of shoulder abduction motion
    • The deltoid muscle abducts the arm beyond 15 degrees
  • Infraspinatus: Lateral (external) rotation of the shoulder
  • Teres Minor: Lateral (external) rotation of the shoulder

The subscapularis originates from the anterior aspect of the lateral border of the scapula and attaches to the lesser tubercle.

Teres minor originates from the posterior aspect of the lateral border of the scapula along with teres major and inserts on the greater tubercle.

Supraspinatus and infraspinatus originate from their respective fossae on the scapula and insert on the greater tubercle.

Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1 page 78

questions.text: Of the types of cells given in this histology image, which of the following sends efferent to the cerebellar nuclei?
questions.solution:
The cells marked 'C' are the Purkinje cells, which provide inhibitory signals to deep nuclei of cerebellum


Reference: Inderbir Singh's textbook of human histology, 8th edition, page 119

questions.text: The given ultrasound image is seen in which week of embryological development?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound image shown above is the double bleb sign, which is seen in 2nd week of development. The two 'blebs' are yolk sac and amniotic sac.

The inner cell mass forms embryoblast, which divides into two layers

  1. Columnar cells called EPIBLAST on the dorsal end, which enclose amniotic cavity
  2. Cuboidal cells called HYPOBLAST on ventral end, which enclose the primitive yolk sac

Reference: textbook of clinical embryology, Vishram Singh, 12edition, page 34

questions.text: Which of the following germ layers is not derived from Epiblast?
questions.solution:
The process of gastrulation begins on 3rd week.

  • Some cells of the hypoblast become columnar at head end and develop to form buccopharyngeal membrane, which ruptures to form the oral cavity.
  • At the head end at epiblast, primitive streak is also formed, which is an indication of gastrulation.
  • 1st germ layer to develop is endoderm, which is derived from epiblast and replaces hypoblast
  • 2nd to develop is mesoderm, which develops from the primitive streak
  • Remainder of epiblast becomes ectoderm.

Thus, all germ layers develop from EPIBLAST.

Reference: textbook of clinical embryology, Vishram Singh, 12edition, page 34

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with the following deformity as shown on the right side of the image. Which of the following bones constitutes the summit of the arch on the medial side?
questions.solution:
• The condition shown above is pes planus, or flat foot, formed by flattening of the medial longitudinal arch, either congenitally or due to acquired causes.
  • The arches shape is designed in a similar manner to spring; bears the weight of the body and absorbs the shock that is produced with locomotion.
  • The foot's flexibility conferred by the arches is what facilitates everyday loco-motor functions such as walking and sprinting.
  • The energy-sparing spring theory of the foot's arch has become central to interpretations of the foot's mechanical function and evolution.
  • The metabolic energy saved by the arch is largely explained by the passive-elastic work it supplies that would otherwise be done by active muscle.

Anatomy Medial, Lateral and Longitudinal arch

Medial Arch:

  • The medial arch is the higher of the two longitudinal arches.
    • It is made up of the calcaneus, the talus, the navicular, the three cuneiforms, and the first, second, and third metatarsals. Its summit is at the superior articular surface of the talus, and its two extremities or piers, on which it rests in standing, are the tuberosity on the plantar surface of the calcaneus posteriorly and the heads of the first, second, and third metatarsal bones anteriorly.
    • The ligament is strengthened medially by blending with the deltoid ligament of the ankle joint and is supported inferiorly by the tendon of the Tibialis posterior, which is spread out in a fan-shaped insertion and prevents undue tension of the ligament or such an amount of stretching as would permanently elongate it.
    • The arch is further supported by the plantar aponeurosis, by the small muscles in the sole of the foot, by the tendons of the Tibialis anterior and posterior and Peroneus longus, and by the ligaments of all the articulations involved.

Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition,volume 2,page189

questions.text: A 43-year-old was posted for partial laryngectomy. For this, the nerve providing sensory supply to the larynx above the vocal cords had to be anesthetized. This nerve can be found coursing through which of the following openings?
questions.solution:
The nerve providing sensory supply to the larynx above the level of vocal cords is internal laryngeal nerve. It passes between middle and inferior constrictor, along with superior laryngeal vessels.

Structures passing through sinus of Morgagni (skull base and superior constrictor)-

  2. Levator palatine
  3. Ascending palatine artery
  4. Palatine branch of ascending pharyngeal artery
  5. Tensor palatini

Structures passing between superior and middle constrictor-

  1. Stylohyoid ligament
  2. 9th cranial nerve
  3. Stylopharyngeus muscle

Below inferior constrictor-

  1. Recurrent laryngeal nerve
  2. Inferior laryngeal vessels

questions.text: A neonate was born with respiratory distress and an inability to insert Ryle's tube. The abdomen of the baby was scaphoid. The paediatrician found a hernia on the left side. This occurs due to a developmental defect in which of the following embryological structures forming the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Bochdalek's hernia is the most common congenital diaphragmatic hernia. It occurs on the left side and is due t a defect in pleuroperitoneal membrane.

The defect is posterolateral

Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1 page 278

questions.text: A 49-year-old lady was diagnosed with dysgerminoma of the ovary. The cancer mass had grown to invade the surrounding structures in the ovarian fossa and involved the nerve forming one of its boundaries. Where will the pain be referred to?
questions.solution:
• The obturator nerve forms the lateral wall of the ovarian fossa, thus the pain from ovarian pathologies is referred to the medial aspect of thigh.
  • The ovarian fossa is a shallow depression on the lateral wall of the pelvis, where in the ovary lies.
  • It has the following boundaries:
    • Superiorly: by the external iliac artery and vein.
    • Anteriorly and inferiorly: by the broad ligament of the uterus.
    • Posteriorly: by the ureter, internal iliac artery and vein.
    • Inferiorly: by the obturator nerve, artery and vein

Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume 2, page 445

questions.text: A 59-year-old man, Randhir comes to the physician because of bilateral blurry vision and difficulty driving at night that has been worsening progressively. His haemoglobin A1c concentration is 8.9%. The patient's eye condition is most likely due to increased activity of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
• This patient's physical examination shows bilateral cataracts, most likely due to his poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus.
  • Aldose reductase catalyses the reduction of glucose to sorbitol, which is subsequently oxidized to fructose by the sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme.
  • At normal blood glucose levels, only a small part of glucose is metabolized via this polyol pathway.
  • However, in chronic hyperglycaemia due to poorly controlled diabetes, sorbitol formation increases significantly, causing osmotic damage in tissues with low sorbitol dehydrogenase activity (e.g., lens, retina, kidney, and myelin sheath).
  • Consequently, patients present with retinopathy, nephropathy, peripheral neuropathy, and bilateral cataracts as seen in this patient.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 152

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy, Lalit appears to be pale with conjunctival pallor and he complains of fatigue and black urine. Labs are as follows:
Haemoglobin: 11 g/dL
Haematocrit: 32%
MCV: 88 fL
Peripheral blood smear findings are shown in the image. An enzyme defect in which of the following pathways is likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• This case is most consistent with a diagnosis of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD).
  • G6P is the first committed enzyme in the HMP shunt and this pathway functions to generate NADPH for neutralizing oxidizing agents.
  • The symptom of fatigue accompanied by pallor immediately suggests that the question deals with an anaemia, a suspicion confirmed by the decreased haemoglobin and haematocrit.
  • The first step to differentiating anaemia is the MCV, which is found to be normal indicating that this case is normocytic anaemia.
  • The black urine is indicative of haemoglobinuria, meaning that this case is intrinsic haemolytic anaemia.
  • Abnormal RBCs on peripheral blood smear and triggering events can be used to further explore the differential.
  • The peripheral blood smear shows Heinz bodies as well as bite cells, both of which are classic findings in G6PD.
  • Of the potential triggering factors listed, a 5K might cause mild haemolysis but would not be associated with anaemia.
  • Similarly, chronic alcoholism can be associated with macrocytic anaemia but acute alcohol use would not lead to this clinical syndrome.
  • The unknown meal likely contained oxidative agents such as fava beans (high yield association) and lead to haemolytic anaemia.
  • G6PD is an enzyme in the HMP shunt and generates NADPH for use in the neutralization of oxidizing agents. Other oxidizing agents such as sulfa drugs can therefore also cause haemolysis.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 147

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant presents with mental retardation, microcephaly, and a mousy odour to his breath. You should be concerned that the infant may have which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The triad of mental retardation, microcephaly, and a mousy odour to the breath and urine is classic for phenylketonuria, which results from deficient activity of phenylalanine hydroxylase.
  • Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disease featuring an inability to break down the aromatic amino acid phenylalanine due to either decreased activity of phenylalanine hydroxylase or decreased tetrahydrobiopterin (THB) cofactor.
  • Phenylalanine must be restricted in the diet, and tyrosine may become essential, though a recent Cochrane review did not demonstrate convincing results.
  • Without strict dietary therapy, the typical clinical picture of mental and growth retardation, seizures, eczema, and a musty body odour develops.

Other Options:

  • Option B: Deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase activity is implicated in acute intermittent porphyria.
  • Option C: Deficiency of tyrosine hydroxylase is implicated in Parkinson's disease and Segawa's dystonia.
  • Option D: Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) deficiency is associated with hyperphenylalaninemia, not excess.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 310

questions.text: Example of a transport defect is?
questions.solution:
• Cystinuria is an inherited autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of cystine in the kidneys and bladder due to a disruption of amino acid transporter function in the proximal convoluted tubule and intestine.

Pathophysiology:

  • Impaired renal reabsorption of dibasic amino acids COLA (cystine, ornithine, arginine, lysine) → accumulation of cystine in the urine → frequent formation of hexagonal cystine stones leading to recurrent nephrolithiasis, starting as early as childhood
  • Urine microscopy shows hexagonal cystine stones and urinary cyanide nitroprusside test is positive.
  • Treatment plan includes increase cystine solubility to counter the formation of renal stones with adequate hydration.
  • Urinary alkalinization with acetazolamide, potassium citrate and chelating agents like penicillamine.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 282

questions.text: Laboratory testing shows normal levels of chylomicrons but dramatically increased levels of LDL. This patient most likely has a deficiency of?
questions.solution:
• Familial hypercholesterolemia, also known as type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia, is a hereditary disease of lipoprotein processing.
  • It is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors.
  • Since the LDL receptor is responsible for uptake of LDL remnants into the liver, patients with this disease have impaired clearance of circulating LDL particles.
  • This results in a dramatically increased risk of coronary artery disease such that heterozygous patients will suffer symptoms of ischemic heart disease in their 30s and homozygous patients will have an even earlier onset of symptoms in their teenage years.
  • Therefore, patients with familial hypercholesterolemia need to be treated very aggressively with lipid-lowering agents.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Apolipoprotein E is deficient in familial dys-beta-lipoproteinemia, which can also present with early-onset coronary artery disease; however, this disease will have elevated levels of chylomicrons in the blood.
  • Option B: Hormone-sensitive lipase causes hydrolysis of triglycerides into fatty acids inside cells and is important in the clearance of triglycerides; however, this enzyme is not involved in the removal of lipoprotein particles from circulation.
  • Option C: Lipoprotein lipase is deficient in hyperchylomicronaemia; however, this disease would present with abdominal pain and other gastrointestinal symptoms rather than early coronary artery disease.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 220

choices.text: Binding of substrate to active site

questions.text: Lock and key hypothesis explain all features, except
questions.solution:
• Lock-and-key model is a model for enzyme-substrate interaction suggesting that the enzyme and the substrate possess specific complementary geometric shapes that fit exactly into one another.
  • Enzymes are highly specific.
  • They must bind to a specific substrate before they can catalyse a chemical reaction.
  • Lock and key hypothesis explain specificity of enzyme action, binding of substrate to active site and 3D shape of active site.
  • However, this model fails to explain the effect of regulatory molecules on enzyme and substrate.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 53

questions.text: Abnormal splicing of the beta globin gene results in B-thalassemia. What is removed during this process that allows RNA to be significantly shorter than DNA?
questions.solution:
• Introns are intervening noncoding segments of DNA that are removed during RNA splicing.
  • RNA splicing is an integral part of RNA processing, where the initial transcript undergoes capping of the 5' end, polyadenylation of the 3' end, and splicing.
  • During splicing, small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs) and other proteins form a spliceosome.
  • A lariat (or loop) is generated in the transcript and the spliceosome releases the lariat to remove the intron and join two exons.
  • Exons contain the actual genetic information that codes for proteins while introns contain noncoding information.
  • It is worth noting that exons can be joined in various combinations via alternative splicing. It is through this process that DNA is often 1,000 to 1,000,000 times larger than RNA.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Exons contain genetic information and are joined together to from the mature RNA.
  • Option C: microRNAs are small, noncoding RNA molecules responsible for regulating gene expression. They are conserved during the splicing process.
  • Option D: snRNPs and other proteins form the spliceosome responsible for carrying out the RNA splicing.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 607

questions.text: Steroid hormone synthesis, lipid synthesis, and chemical detoxification are activities of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is involved in steroid synthesis, chemical detoxification, lipid metabolism and gluconeogenesis.
  • High concentrations of smooth ER are found in hepatocytes, kidney, adrenal cortex, and corpus luteum.
  • In muscle a modified smooth ER called the sarcoplasmic reticulum releases calcium for muscle contraction.

Other Options:

  • Option A: The main function of the rough ER is the ribosome-mediated synthesis of proteins.
  • Option B: The Golgi apparatus is a site for the trafficking of proteins and lipids.
  • Option C: Peroxisomes contain several enzymes necessary for oxidative processes.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 22

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman comes with generalized dry skin, multiple bruises on the shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal conjunctiva. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
• This patient's dry skin, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva is consistent with a specific vitamin deficiency.
  • Vitamin A deficiency (retinol deficiency) can be seen in conditions of fat malabsorption, such as inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease), celiac disease, cystic fibrosis, and pancreatic insufficiency.
  • Because vitamin A is involved in epithelial cell differentiation and retinal pigmentation, retinol deficiency results in dermatological and ophthalmological manifestations, such as xerosis cutis and Bitot spots.
  • A deficiency in vitamin A can also cause immunosuppression, which explains this patient's recurrent upper respiratory tract infections.
  • Moreover, this patient's recent history of stumbling in the dark most likely results from night blindness (nyctalopia), another common manifestation of vitamin A deficiency.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 487

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has felt increasingly tired despite no changes in her diet or exercise. Her family history is notable for colorectal cancer in her mother and maternal uncle, endometrial cancer in her maternal aunt, and ovarian cancer in her maternal grandmother. A stool sample is hemoccult positive. A colonoscopy reveals a fungating haemorrhagic mass in the ascending colon. Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient in this vignette presents with a colonic malignancy and has a significant family history of colorectal, endometrial, and ovarian cancer suggestive of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC is caused by a mutation in DNA mismatch repair enzymes.
  • Mismatch repair is one of several forms of DNA repair that is particularly useful in repairing mispairings between nucleotide base pairs.
  • HNPCC, also known as Lynch syndrome, is caused by hereditary absences in one copy of one of the enzymes necessary for mismatch repair.
  • If the second copy is lost by somatic mutation, this leads to a 'second hit' and an inability to manage nucleotide mismatches.
  • Errors in mismatch repair lead to microsatellite instability, which is characterized by di-, tri-, or tetranucleotide repeats that can be amplified and lead to an increased risk of cancer.
  • HNPCC therefore presents with an increased risk of colorectal cancer (without preceding benign polyps), ovarian, endometrial, small bowel, gastric, and pancreatic malignancies.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 575

questions.text: Which one of the following antidotes is not used to treat copper poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Desferrioxamine is not an antidote used to treat copper poisoning.
  • It is selectively used as a chelating agent to manage cases of acute iron poisoning, hemochromatosis, and patients with iron overload from repetitive blood transfusions.

Other options:

  • Options A, B, and D: Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), British anti-lewisite (BAL), and penicillamine are used as antidotes in cases of copper poisoning.

References: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page No. 570

questions.text: Which of the following changes gives an indication of the cause and manner of death?
questions.solution:
• Cadaveric spasm is an antemortem change that gives an indication of the cause and manner of death.
  • The victims do not undergo post-mortem flaccidity (unlike rigor mortis), thereby directly entering a state of instantaneous rigor. This results in muscle stiffening which indicates the victim's attitude at the time of death. Cadaveric spasm is limited to select muscles i.e., the muscles that were in a state of contraction at the time of death. The mechanism of cadaveric spasm is thought to be due to neurogenic phenomena.
  • Predisposing factors for this post-mortem change include excitement, fear, fatigue, electrocution, nervous system injury, and convulsant poisons such as strychnine.
  • It persists for a few hours following which, it is replaced by the rigor mortis.
  • The image shown above represents a firm hand grip on weeds and mud, found in a victim of drowning.
  • It is indicative of the last action performed by the victim. This is an example of cadaveric spasm.

Other options:

  • Option 1 - Rigor mortis is a post-mortem phenomenon indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level. It appears 2-3 hours after death and is usually preceded by post-mortem flaccidity. It involves both the voluntary and involuntary muscles of the body and persists for about 12-24 hours.
  • Option 2 - Cold stiffening is a post-mortem phenomenon that is seen in bodies exposed to temperatures below 3.5 degrees Celsius (40 degrees Fahrenheit). The mechanism involves temperature-induced solidification of fat and muscle. Rigor mortis is suspended in these victims and sets in only after thawing.
  • Option 3 - Heat stiffening is a post-mortem phenomenon that is seen in bodies exposed to temperatures above 65 degrees Celsius (149 degrees Fahrenheit). Characteristic rigidity is from heat-induced protein coagulation that causes postural changes due to muscle contraction (pugilistic or boxer's attitude).
  • The postural changes as seen in cold and heat stiffening occur post-mortem in response to the temperature changes to which the body is exposed.

References:& Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology Page nos. 37

questions.solution:
Square orbits located lower on the face indicate a male skeleton.

The female skull has round orbits with sharp margins and they are placed higher on the face.

choices.text: No pupillary changes in response to light
Absent eye movements in response to caloric testing

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardinal finding in patients who are declared brain dead?
questions.solution:
Cough response to bronchial suction is indicative of normal cough reflex and is, therefore not a cardinal finding in brain death.

The 3 cardinal features of brain death include:

  1. Unresponsiveness or coma- demonstrated by an absent motor response to pain in all extremities.
  2. Apnoea- impaired brainstem activity indicates damage to the medullary cardio-respiratory centres. This manifests as a loss of centrally controlled breathing.
  3. Absence of brainstem reflexes -
  • Cranial nerve Il, III (optic and oculomotor)- absent direct and consensual light reflex. This is associated with dilated pupils measuring about 9 mm.
  • Cranial nerve VIll (vestibulocochlear)- absent oculocephalic (Doll's eye phenomenon) and oculovestibular (unresponsive to caloric testing) reflexes.
  • Cranial nerve V, VIl (trigeminal and facial)- absent corneal and jaw reflexes.
  • Cranial nerve IX, X (glossopharyngeal and vagus)- absent cough and gag reflexes.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects Page No. 127

choices.text: Request police officer for a court order
Refuse to carry out medical examination without consent
Wait until the accused gives consent

questions.text: A police sub-inspector brings an accused of rape to a doctor and requests a medical examination. He believes that examination findings would yield evidence to prove the offense allegedly committed. However, the accused not cooperative. Which of the following is the next course of action by the doctor?
questions.solution:
• The doctor must perform the medical examination by force.
  • 53 CrPC deals with the examination of an accused by a doctor using force, in the event that the examination has been requested by a police officer (designation of Sub-Inspector and above).
  • The intention behind such a request must be to procure evidence regarding the offense allegedly committed by the accused (Sec. 53(1) CrPC).
  • If the person is accused of rape, a medical examination may be carried out by force (in the event of non-cooperation) by the provisions made by Sec. 53A CrPC.
  • If the accused person is female, the medical examination must be carried only by, or under the direct supervision of a female doctor (Sec 53(2) CrPC).
  • Such an examination is applicable to the testing of blood, blood stains, semen, swabs, sputum, hair samples, and fingernail clippings
  • Other options:
  • Consent is mandatory for the examination of a victim in criminal cases. Performing an examination by force or by availing of a court order is not allowed for the examination of a victim.
  • However, as mentioned above, the accused may be examined by force if requested by a police officer with the intention of revealing evidence that could incriminate the accused.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page Nos. 373

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is arrested under Sec. 290 IPC for rubbing his genitals against a female passenger in the local bus. Which one of the following terms describes this particular sexual offense?
questions.solution:
• Frotteurism is the term used to describe the sexual offense presented in the question.
  • It is the non-consensual act of rubbing one's genitals against another person for the purpose of sexual arousal and gratification.
  • Offenders are usually males and these offenses are prone to occur in crowded trains and buses.
  • If the offender fondles or gropes the victim, it is known as toucherism.
  • This sexual offense is liable to punishment under the Sec. 290 IPC (fine of Rs. 200/-) as well as Sec. 291 IPC (imprisonment for 6 months and/ or fine) for creating a nuisance to the public.

Other options

  • Option A - Voyeurism is a sexual offense wherein the alleged offender(voyeur) observes/ spies on unsuspecting people in varying stages of undress, while they take baths or engage in intercourse with their partners. Their purpose is to obtain sexual gratification. It is a punishable sexual offense under Sec. 354-C IPC by imprisonment (1-3 years) and fine. 2nd offense is liable to punishment by imprisonment for 3-7 years.
  • Option C - Exhibitionism is a sexual offense characterized by intentional genital exposure in public spaces, usually directed towards unsuspecting children and females, to obtain sexual gratification. Offenders are commonly called flashers. This offense is liable to punishment under Sec. 294 IPC (imprisonment up to 3 months with/without fine).
  • Option D - Masochism is a type of paraphilia wherein the person achieves sexual gratification when they receive painful stimulus from their sexual partner. There may be instances of asphyxia death (accidental hanging or strangulation) during masochistic sexual acts. These are termed autoerotic deaths.

Reference: Review Of Forensic Medicine And toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects Page Nos. 394

questions.text: The sequence of bullet injuries in the following image can be identified by?
questions.solution:
• The sequence of gunshots, in this case, is 1-> 2-> 3 according to Puppe's rule.
  • Puppe's rule states that the path of a second fracture line does not cross the path of an existing fracture line that appears or was caused before it. This helps the forensic expert determine the chronology (order) in which the bullets were lodged into the skull.
  • Puppe's rule is used in forensic examination of skull fractures caused by multiple blunt force vectors as well, as it is not limited to the examination of bullet injuries only.

References: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition

choices.text: Cricoid pressure of 30 N is required
Failure of the jaw to relax following suxamethonium may necessitate a second dose.

questions.text: In rapid sequence induction, which of the following is true
questions.solution:
• Although rocuronium is used it does not strictly speaking represent a safe technique.
  • If intubation fails the patient will not return to spontaneous ventilation before hypoxia ensues.
  • In order to suppress the haemodynamic response to laryngoscopy and intubation, it may be necessary in at-risk patients to administer a short acting opioid prior to induction.
  • This can be reversed with naloxone in the event of a failed intubation if required.
  • Preoxygenation for 3-5 min with a close-fitting face mask or 4-5 vital capacity breaths when there is not enough time is sufficient.
  • Failure of the jaw to relax following the administration of suxamethonium should lead to the suspicion of malignant hyperpyrexia and the institution of a failed intubation drill followed by close observation.

Reference: Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 1: Chapter 2

choices.text: Is metabolised to inorganic fluoride ions
Has been implicated in the causation of seizures

questions.text: Isoflurane is an Inhalational anaesthetic with all the following features except:
questions.solution:
• Isoflurane is a halogenated methyl ether and a structural isomer of enflurane. It is a respiratory depressant by reducing tidal volume.
  • Only 0.2% is metabolised in the liver by oxidation and dehalogenation.
  • It causes a drop in systemic vascular resistance with a compensatory tachycardia. Enflurane is epileptogenic.

Reference: Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 3, p 597

questions.text: Pick the true statement in regards to Thiopentone sodium
questions.solution:
• Thiopentone is a thiobarbiturate presented as a yellow powder and reconstituted in water to yield a 2.5% solution with a pH of 10.8 and pKa of 7.6.
  • It is a negative inotrope and decreases systemic vascular resistance leading to hypotension.
  • Cerebral blood flow, intracranial pressure and intraocular pressure all fall.

Reference: Sasada M, Smith S. Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, 2nd Edn. Oxford University Press, 1997

questions.text: A man was admitted involuntarily after he tried to hit his neighbour on hearing the neighbour's voices wanting to take over his house. He was diagnosed with psychosis and started on Olanzapine. He had to be given Haloperidol injections for quite a few times after admission when he became agitated and tried to leave the ward. Since the last 3 days, he appears confused and disoriented. He has severe muscle rigidity and a temperature of 39.4°C (103°F). His blood pressure is elevated, and he has a leucocytosis. Which of the following is used in the pharmacologic treatment of this man?
questions.solution:
• The patient has neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), a life-threatening complication of antipsychotic treatment.
  • The symptoms include muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agitation. The autonomic symptoms include high fever, sweating, and increased blood pressure and heart rate. Mortality rates are reported to be 10% to 20%.
  • In addition to supportive medical treatment, the most commonly used medications for the condition are dantrolene (Dantrium) followed by bromocriptine (Parlodel), although amantadine is sometimes used.
  • Bromocriptine and amantadine possess direct dopamine receptor agonist effects and may serve to overcome the antipsychotic-induced dopamine receptor blockade. Dantrolene is a direct muscle relaxant.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's, Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, Chapter 29 Psychopharmacological Treatment, page no. 925

questions.text: 'Schizophrenia' is the term given by?
questions.solution:
• Bleuler coined the term 'Schizophrenia' which replaced the term 'Dementia precox' termed by Emil Kraepelin, who translated Benedict Morels term 'Demence precoce'.
  • He chose the term to express the presence of schisms among though, emotion and behaviour in patients with this disorder. (Split Personality, also called dissociative identity disorder differs completely from Schizophrenia)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 7.1 Schizophrenia, page no. 300

questions.text: Panic attacks are usually seen in:
questions.solution:
• Panic attacks are usually seen in disorders like Specific phobia, Social phobia, OCD, Post-traumatic stress disorder.
  • Also, it can occur in course of several other psychiatric disorders like depression, personality disorders, substance use disorders.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 9.2, Panic Disorder, Page 395

questions.text: In a patient of PTSD, a psychotherapeutic technique is practiced in which the patient focuses on the lateral movement of the clinician's finger while maintaining a mental image of the trauma experience. The general belief is that symptoms can be relieved as patients work through the traumatic event while in a state of deep relaxation. What is this technique called?
questions.solution:
• A variant of trauma-focused CBT for PTSD is called eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), in which an exposure and cognitive reprocessing interventions are paired with directed eye movements.
  • In this, the patient focuses on the lateral movement of the clinician's finger while maintaining a mental image of the trauma experience.
  • The general belief is that symptoms can be relieved as patients work through the traumatic event while in a state of deep relaxation.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 11, Trauma and stressor related disorders, Page 445

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department. She is unresponsive to questions, stumbles around the room, and is agitated. On physical examination, you notice that she smells of alcohol, and she is not cooperative during the remainder of the examination. Administration of what medicine would be the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
• The most appropriate treatment is the immediate administration of thiamine.
  • This patient presents with Wernicke encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of delirium, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.
  • Thiamine must be given prior to glucose in patients suspected of having this disorder.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 20.2 Alcohol-related disorders, page no. 637

choices.text: Application of a wound VAC of the soft tissue defect in the ED
Operative debridement within 6 to 8 hours of injury

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the trauma centre with a significantly deformed right lower extremity with a 4-cm wound over the posteromedial portion of her leg. She is found to have a Gustilo and Anderson type 3A fracture. Which of the following interventions has been shown to decrease the risk of infection at the fracture site?
questions.solution:
• The duration to beginning of antibiotic administration and adequate surgical debridement of the wound are the only factors definitively shown to reduce infection and improve outcome in open fractures.
  • Although traditional recommendations include surgical irrigation and debridement within 6 to 8 hours of injury, there is no literature to support this time window.
  • There is also no evidence to support pulsatile lavage over gravity flow. Finally, in this setting there is also no role for wound VAC application in the ED.

Open tibia fractures are high-energy injuries, and as such, evaluation and treatment of life-threatening injuries per ATLS protocol is the first priority.

-Systemic antibiotics must be started as soon as possible; a delay of >3 hours increase the risk of infection.

-It is recommended that operative irrigation and debridement be performed within 6 to 8 hours from the time of injury, although there is little evidence to support this.

-Initial stabilization of open tibia fractures includes external fixation and intramedullary nailing.

-The predominant risk associated with open fractures is infection, which can lead to amputation, loss of function, delayed union, malunion, or nonunion.

Reference: Zalavras CG, Patzakis MJ. Open fractures: evaluation and management. J Am Acad Orthopaed Surg.2003;11:212-219.

questions.text: A 40-year-old right-handed professional football player reports persistent right wrist pain after falling during a game 5 days ago. A radiograph is shown in Figure. The diagnosis of the given image?
questions.solution:
• Given X ray shows scaphoid-lunate instability
  • Scaphoid - Most common carpal bone to fracture
  • Scapho-Lunate dissociation -Gap between scaphoid & lunate Shows Terry Thomas sign/David letterman sign on X-ray.
  • Terry-Thomas sign indicates scapholunate instability
  • It denotes the increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate.
  • It results from tearing of the scapholunate ligament following fall on outstretched hand.
  • A scapholunate gap of >3 mm is suggestive of instability.
  • The given X-ray shows the Terry-Thomas sign and the image shows comedian Terry- Thomas, after whom this sign has been named:

Reference: Egol, K. A., Koval, K. J., & Zuckerman, J. D. (Eds.). (2020). Glenohumeral Dislocation. In Handbook of Fractures(6th ed., pp.307). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

questions.text: A 24-year-old overweight individual was walking on the pedestrian footpath and tried to get down he twisted his feet causing inversion. What is the commonest ligament injured in this injury?
questions.solution:
In the given case there is Ankle Ligament Injury

  • The most common mode of ankle injury is an inversion of the plantar flexed foot.
  • Commonest ligament injured: Anterior talofibular ligament

Risk factors of Ankle ligament injury:

  • High Body mass index
  • Slow eccentric inversion strength
  • Fast concentric plantar flexion strength
  • Passive inversion of joint position.

Reference: Egol, K. A., Koval, K. J., & Zuckerman, J. D. (Eds.). (2020). Injuries about the Ankle . In Handbook of Fractures(6th ed., pp. 482-511). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with acute onset pain and swelling of left great toe. On X-ray, punched out lytic lesion seen on phalanx with sclerotic margins and overhanging bony edges. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Gout is a metabolic disease that mostly occurs in middle-aged to elderly men and postmenopausal women. It results from an increased body pool of urate with hyperuricemia.
  • In typically is characterized by episodic acute and chronic arthritis caused by deposition of MSU crystals in joints and connective tissue tophi and the risk for deposition in kidney interstitium or uric acid nephrolithiasis.
  • Disturbed purine metabolism leading to excessive accumulation of uric acid in the blood - an inherited disorder; or impaired excretion of uric acid by the kidneys. The result is accumulation of sodium biurate crystals in some soft tissues. Tissues of predilection are cartilage, tendon, bursa
  • Usually, only one joint is affected initially and the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is the most commonly involved joint-
  • Patient, usually beyond 40 years of age, presents as
  • arthritis - MP joint of the big toe being a favourite site, onset is acute, pain is severe;
  • bursitis - commonly of the olecranon bursa; or
  • tophi formation deposit of uric acid salt in the soft tissue

X-ray changes include:

- Soft tissue swelling (may be the only sign during acute attack)

- Periarticular deep erosions

- Joint space narrowing

- G sign/Martel sign:-Punched out lesion of bone with overhanging bony edges.

Confirmation of diagnosis - urate crystals in the aspirate from a joint or bursa, high serum uric acid levels

Treatment - NSAIDs, uricosuric drugs, uric acid inhibitors.

Reference: maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 293.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the back. Lab investigation shows elevated ESR. X ray skull shows below findings. What is the most important investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
Multiple Myeloma: -

  • This classical finding indicates towards Multiple myeloma Lytic tumour
  • Plasma cells (destroys whole body/ bone)
  • Features: Bone pain + High ESR + Hypercalcemia
  • Criteria
  1. M proteins in serum / urine
  2. Bone marrow plasma cells/ Plasmacytosis
  3. End organ damage like Lesion, anemia hypercalcemia, ↑ creatinine, hyper viscosity, amyloidosis, bacterial infection (> 2 episodes per year)
  • Plasma cell leukaemia > 20% plasma cells in peripheral smear
  • Diagnosis: M bands on serum electrophoresis. Abnormal spike in the region of gamma globulin (myeloma spike)is present in 90 per cent of cases.
  • Elevated ESR is an important finding in multiple myeloma
  • Radiological examination: Multiple punched out lesions in the skull and other flat bones, Pathological wedge collapse of the vertebra

Treatment:-Melphalan is the drug of choice. It is given in combination with Vincristine, Prednisolone, and sometimes Cyclophosphamide. The cycles are repeated every 3-4 weeks for 6-12 cycles.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 245

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought to emergency department with a neck injury Cervical collar following RTA was applied on site. On further investigation there is a stable burst fracture of the C1 vertebra. What is the mechanism of injury in this case?
questions.solution:
• Jefferson fracture is burst fracture of ring of atlas (C1) vertebrae.
  • Burst fracture occurs due to vertical compression force.
  • In Jefferson's fracture (burst fracture of the atlas) the patient usually presents with neck pain but no neurological deficit. But if there is a retro-pulsed fragment spinal cord injury may Occur.
  • The fracture is identified on the open-mouth X ray view (odontoid view) with displacement of C1 relative to C2.
  • A CT scan will confirm and define the fracture.
  • If C1 overhang on C2>7mm on the open mouth view, the transverse ligament is likely to be ruptured (rule of Spence), making the injury unstable and should be treated by halo-vest for several weeks. And if there is persistent instability on X-ray then posterior C1/2 fixation and fusion is needed.
  • There is seldom a neurological injury. Fractures of the atlas are associated with injury elsewhere in the cervical spine in up to 50% of cases.

Management of burst fractures:

Stable burst fracture: In minimal anterior wedging and when the fracture is stable (posterior ligament complex intact), with no neurological deficits conservative treatment is followed. Bed rest until acute symptoms settle, followed by a thoracolumbar brace (TLSO) or body cast for about 12 weeks.

Unstable burst fracture: Operative treatment is done in cases of neurological injury, disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex (PLC), and if there is more than 50% canal compromise on CT. Posterior pedicle screw fixation is the standard treatment for PLC disruption.

Reference: ebnezar 5th edition page no 307.

questions.text: Which of the following is an epiphyseal tumor?
questions.solution:
CHONDROBLASTOMA:

  • This benign tumor of immature cartilage cells is one of the few lesions to appear primarily in the epiphysis, usually of the proximal humerus, femur or tibia.
  • The presenting symptom is a constant ache in the joint; the tender spot is actually in the adjacent bone.
  • X-ray shows a rounded, well-demarcated radiolucent area in the epiphysis with no hint of central calcification.

Tumors according to their Origin Site in long bone

Reference: Apley's System of Orthopaedics, 9th ed. pg. 198

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby which was delivered by breech presentation was brought to the OPD. On examination, you notice there is asymmetry of thigh folds, with limited abduction of thigh there is a click sound. What is the treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is Developmental dysplasia of Hip

  • Pavlik harness is the treatment of choice in child less than 6 month.

Treatment Plan of DDH:

  • Neonate and Young Child (1-6 month) Closed reduction.
  • Pavlik harness is the treatment of choice

PAVLIK HARNEESS-

  • abduction orthosis used in age group less than 6 months old child.
  • Splintage for Developmental dysplasia of hip
  • The most widely used device in management of developmental dysplasia of hip in Pavlik harness.
  • This device prevents adduction and extension while allowing further flexion, abduction and rotation. This position allows for gentle spontaneous reduction of dislocated hip.
  • Stretching of the tight adductors is also possible with the Pavlik harness.
  • The device is worn full time till the hip stability is achieved

IN 6 to 18 months: Closed reduction, and spica casting.

IN 18 months to 3 years: Open reduction

IN 3 years or more: Various Osteotomies required to keep the head of femur into the acetabulum e.g. Salter's, Dega's, Pemberton's

Reference: Turek orthopaedics: Principles and their application p. 449

questions.text: A child with delayed puberty has low levels of FSH, LH and testosterone. Which of the following is most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The child has hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. The causes are:

  • CNS Disorders
    • Tumors
      • Craniopharyngiomas
      • Germinomas
      • Other germ cell tumors
      • Hypothalamic and optic gliomas
      • Astrocytomas
      • Pituitary tumors (including MEN-1, prolactinoma)
    • Other Causes
      • Langerhans histiocytosis
      • Postinfectious lesions of the CNS
      • Vascular abnormalities of the CNS
      • Radiation therapy
      • Congenital malformations, especially associated with craniofacial anomalies
      • Head trauma
      • Lymphocytic hypophysitis
    • Isolated Gonadotropin Deficiency
      • Kallmann syndrome
        • With hyposmia or anosmia
        • Without anosmia
      • LHRH receptor mutation
      • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 mutation)
      • Isolated LH deficiency
      • Isolated FSH deficiency
      • Prohormone convertase 1 deficiency (PCI)

Reference: Nelson symptom-based diagnosis, pg. 785

questions.text: The diet of a 3-year-old child with cystic fibrosis should be supplemented with which of the following?

choices.text: Administration of intravenous immunoglobulin to the baby to decrease the risk of perinatal HIV infection
Beginning a course of zidovudine for the infant

questions.text: A term infant is born to a 23-year-old known HIV-positive mother. The mother has been followed closely during the pregnancy, and she has been taking antiretroviral medications for the weeks prior to the delivery. Routine management of the healthy infant should include which of the following?
questions.solution:
• HIV transmission from mother to infant has decreased dramatically over the last 20 years, probably as a result of perinatal antiretroviral administration to the mother and a zidovudine course to the exposed infant.
  • Trans-placentally transmitted maternal HIV antibodies will result in a positive neonatal ELISA; it is not a useful test for determining new-born infection. Intravenous immunoglobulin has not been shown to have a role in decreasing perinatal transmission. Healthy infants born to HIV-infected mothers require neither special monitoring nor routine radiographs.

Reference: NACO guidelines for PPTCT

questions.text: Identify the type of injury of the urinary bladder as shown below?
questions.solution:
In the presented case, excretory phase CT demonstrates contrast extravasation into the peritoneal cavity as evidenced by contrast pooling into the rectovesical pouch; thus, suggesting an intraperitoneal injury. A CT cystography can be used to determine the presence of bladder rupture without a need for further delaying examination.

Sandler et al. divided the bladder injuries into five types, as follows:

  • type I: contusion - partial or incomplete tear of the mucosa
  • type II: intraperitoneal rupture - usually caused by blunt trauma while the patient has a distended bladder, allowing for rupture of the bladder dome
  • type III: interstitial injury - intramural or partial-thickness laceration with an intact serosa
  • type IV: extraperitoneal - most commonly seen in penetrating trauma
  • type V: combined rupture - simultaneous intra- and extraperitoneal rupture

Reference: Carmo, R. Traumatic intraperitoneal bladder rupture. Case study, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-50583

questions.text: Which investigation is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a mammogram. Mammography is primarily a screening and not a diagnostic tool.
  • The mediolateral oblique (MLO) and craniocaudal (CC) views are standard screening views, whereas additional views described used mainly for diagnostic evaluation of lesions.
  • The ACS recommends annual screening mammography for all women starting at 40 years of age, monthly self-breast examination beginning at 20 years of age, and an annual physical breast examination by a health care professional every 3 years (ages 20-39) and annually starting at age 40.
  • The baseline study is no longer part of ACS screening guidelines.

Reference: Primer of diagnostic Imaging, sixth edition Pg 561

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
• Paget disease of the bone is a common, chronic bone disorder characterized by excessive abnormal bone remodelling.
  • The classically described radiological appearances are expanded bone with a coarsened trabecular pattern. The pelvis, spine, skull, and proximal long bones are most frequently affected. Plain radiographic features will depend upon the phase of the disease.
  • The early phase features osteolytic (lucent) regions which are later followed by coarsened trabeculae and bony enlargement. Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. Additional destructive features may become apparent if malignant transformation occurs.
  • Skull
  • osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner aspect of the outer table of the skull (stage one) with a preserved inner table.
  • cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.
  • diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o' Shanter sign: platybasia and basilar invagination with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat
  • Spine
  • picture frame sign: Paget disease of the spine frequently manifests with cortical thickening and sclerosis encasing the vertebral margins, which gives rise to this appearance on radiographs in mixed-phase disease
  • squaring of vertebrae: on lateral radiographs, flattening of the normal concavity of the anterior margin of the vertebral body also adds to the rectangular appearance
  • vertical trabecular thickening: coarser than the more delicate pattern seen in intraosseous hemangiomas with which it may be confused

Pelvis

  • cortical thickening and sclerosis of the iliopectineal and ischiopubic lines results in the pelvic brim sign and leads to obliteration of Köhler's teardrop
  • acetabular protrusion
  • enlargement of the pubic rami and ischium

These findings are often asymmetric, and for some reason, are more commonly seen on the right side.

Long bones

  • blade of grass or candle flame sign: begins as a subchondral area of lucency with advancing tip of V-shaped osteolysis, extending towards the diaphysis
    • in rare cases, the disease is isolated to the diaphysis, most commonly in the tibia, rather than subchondral bone, which can cause diagnostic confusion
  • lateral curvature (bowing) of the femur
  • anterior curvature of the tibia

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2743

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of the given below image?
questions.solution:
Complete white-out of a hemithorax on the chest x-ray has a limited number of causes.

Trachea pulled toward the opacified side

  • pneumonectomy
  • total lung collapse: e.g., endobronchial intubation
  • pulmonary agenesis
  • pulmonary hypoplasia

Trachea remains central in position

  • consolidation
  • pulmonary oedema/ARDS
  • pleural mass: e.g., mesothelioma
  • chest wall mass: e.g., Askin/Ewing sarcoma
  • being on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) 4,5

Pushed away from the opacified side

  • pleural effusion
  • diaphragmatic hernia
  • large pulmonary mass
  • diaphragmatic rupture

Reference: Dawes, L., El-Feky, M. Hemithorax white-out (differential). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-1439.

questions.text: Which is the commonest nerve involved in the leprosy?
questions.solution:
• Major peripheral nerves are frequently affected in leprosy : posterior tibial > ulnar > median> lateral popliteal > facial nerves.
  • These nerves are involved at the most superficial location of their course and at major sites of predilection.
  • For example: ulnar in the upper arm above the elbow,
  • Median nerve behind the wrist at the flexor retinaculum,
  • Posterior tibial at the ankle below and behind the medial malleolus.

Reference: IAL textbook of leprosy, 2nd edition page 403

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painless ulcers on penis. It started as painless nodules that slowly evolved to red ulcer. History of unprotected intercourse with CSW 2 months prior. Physical examination revealed multiple beefy red exuberant non tender round ulcers of various sizes on shaft of penis. What is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• These granuloma inguinale lesions develop from nodular lesions and consist of large, usually painless, expanding, suppurative ulcers.
  • The ulcers have clean, friable bases with distinct, raised, rolled margins and have a tendency to bleed easily.
  • The ulcers are 'beefy red' and slowly expand centrifugally, eventually becoming more granulomatous with serpiginous borders.
  • They are commonly located in the skin folds, and autoinoculation is a common feature, resulting in lesions on adjacent skin.
  • Ulcers often become secondarily infected with other types of bacteria and emit a putrid odour.

Reference: Sexually transmitted infection 2nd edition Pg 625

questions.text: Aniseikonia means-
questions.solution:
Definition:
