questions.text: A 30 years old male from a rural background presents to ophthalmology clinic with history of difficulty in vision since l0 days. He gives history of vegetative material falling in left eye about 15 days back. On examination an ulcerative lesion in the cornea with feathery margins and creamy exudates is seen, few satellite lesions were also noted. The most likely diagnosis etiologic agent is:
questions.solution:
Common predisposing factors to keratitis:

  1. Trauma
  2. Contact lens wear
  3. Pre-existing corneal diseases-trauma, bullous keratopathy, and decreased corneal sensation.
  4. Other factors-chronic blepharoconjunctivitis, dacryocystitis, tear film deficiency, topical steroid therapy, hypovitaminosis.

A typical feature of fungal keratitis.

  1. Signs more than symptoms
  2. Feathery margins
  3. Raised dry surface
  4. Satellite lesions
  5. Endothelial plaques
  6. Cheesy hypopyon
  7. Gritty texture while scraping.

Reference: Parson 22/e, P. 45

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with history of recurrent headache was sent for fundus evaluation. He was found to be having generalized arterial attenuation with multiple cotton wool spots and flame shaped haemorrhages in both eyes' The most likely cause is
questions.solution:
• The arteriosclerotic changes of hypertensive retinopathy are caused by chronically elevated blood pressure, defined as SBP greater than 140 mmHg and DBP greater than 90 mmHg.
  • Primary hypertension is usually essential and not secondary to another disease process. Essential hypertension is a polygenic disease with multiple modifiable environmental factors contributing to the disease.
  • However, secondary hypertension can develop in the setting of pheochromocytoma, primary hyperaldosteronism, Cushing's syndrome, renal parenchymal disease, renal vascular disease, coarctation of the aorta, obstructive sleep apnea, hyperparathyroidism, and hyperthyroidism.
  • Many young patients with secondary hypertension may actually present to an ophthalmologist with bilateral vision loss due to serous macular detachment, bilateral optic disc edema, and exudative retinal detachment. In addition, genetic factors have been found to be associated with a higher risk of hypertensive retinopathy.

Pathophysiology

Hypertensive retinopathy goes through vasoconstrictive, sclerotic, and exudative phases based upon the extent of hypertension control.

  • Vasoconstrictive Phase:

In the vasoconstrictive phase, due to the elevated luminal pressures, local autoregulatory mechanisms cause retinal arteriole narrowing and vasospasm to reduce flow.

  • Sclerotic Phase:

In the sclerotic phase, the layers of the endothelial wall undergo changes such as intimal thickening, medial hyperplasia, and hyaline degradation in the arteriolar[10] worsening arteriolar narrowing, AV crossing changes, and silver and copper wiring.

Exudative Phase:

In the exudative phase, there is a disruption of the blood-brain barrier and leakage of plasma and blood causing retinal hemorrhages, hard exudates, retinal ischemia, and necrosis of smooth muscle.

  • Retinal haemorrhages (develop when necrotic vessels bleed into either the superficial retina (nerve fibre layer) (flame shaped haemorrhage) or the inner retina (dot blot haemorrhage). Cotton wool spots are caused by ischemia to the nerve fibre layer secondary to fibrinous necrosis and luminal narrowing.
  • Ischemia to the nerve fibres leads to decreased axoplasmic flow, nerve swelling, and ultimately fluffy opacification.
  • Exudates occur later in the course of disease, surrounding areas of haemorrhage, as a result of lipid accumulation.
  • Malignant hypertension can cause papilledema which is a result of both leakage and ischemia of arterioles supplying the optic disc that undergo fibrinous necrosis. Ischemia causes optic nerve edema, while leakage causes haemorrhage and disc edema.
  • Of note, the severity and degree of malignant hypertension corresponds to changes of renal function highlighting the multi-organ damage caused by systemic microvascular dysfunction.

The signs of malignant hypertension are well summarized by the Modified Scheie Classification of Hypertensive Retinopathy:

  • Grade 0: No changes
  • Grade 1: Barely detectable arterial narrowing
  • Grade 2: Obvious arterial narrowing with focal irregularities (Figure 1)
  • Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages, exudates, cotton wool spots, or retinal edema (Figure 3)
  • Grade 4: Grade 3 plus papilledema (Figure 4)

The signs of chronic arteriosclerotic hypertension are also summarized by the Scheie Classification:

  • Stage 1: Widening of the arteriole light reflex
  • Stage 2: Stage 1 + Arteriovenous crossing sign (Figure 3)
  • Stage 3: Copper wiring of arterioles (copper colored arteriole light reflex)
  • Stage 4: Silver wiring of arterioles (silver colored arteriole light reflex).

Another classification schema is the Keith-Wagner-Barker classification proposed in 1939.

  • Grade 1: Mild, generalized constriction of retinal arterioles
  • Grade 2: Definite focal narrowing of retinal arterioles + AV nicking
  • Grade 3: Grade 2 + flame-shaped hemorrhages + cotton-wool spots + hard exudates
  • Grade 4: Severe Grade 3 retinopathy + papilledema or retinal edema of specific interest is the classification of hypertensive retinopathy by Wong and Mitchell (2004) in which the worsening grades of retinopathy were more strongly associated with systemic issues. The classification is as follows:
  • None: no detectable signs
  • Mild: one or more of the following: generalized arteriolar narrowing, focal arteriolar narrowing, arteriovenous nicking, opacity (copper wiring) of arteriolar wall
  • Moderate: one or more of the following: retinal hemorrhage (blot, dot, or flame-shaped), microaneurysm, cotton-wool spot, hard exudate, or a combination of these signs
  • Severe: moderate retinopathy plus swelling of the optic disc

Reference: Yanoff 3/e, p. 625

questions.text: A 68-year-old female patient is seen on the ward. She had complained of severe pain in her right eye. There is blurring of vision and she feels nauseated and has vomited several times. Earlier in the day she has undergone colonoscopy for evaluation of her long-standing Crohn's disease. The endoscopist has made a comment that the examination was difficult. What is the likely cause of her painful red eye?
questions.solution:
• Anterior means that the front portion of the uvea, the iris and ciliary body, are primarily affected by the inflammation.
  • The anterior part of the uvea is the iris that surrounds the pupil and the adjacent ciliary body that synthesizes aqueous humour, the fluid that fills the front of the eye.
  • Inflammatory cells in anterior uveitis may therefore be seen in the anterior chamber (iritis), and sometimes the anterior vitreous (behind the lens, in iridocyclitis).
  • Acute disease is characterized by a sudden onset and limited duration.
  • The symptoms of acute anterior uveitis are pain, redness, and photophobia (sensitivity to light), that typically develop rapidly, over a few days.
  • The symptoms will resolve with appropriate anti-inflammatory therapy. If therapy can be tapered and inflammation does not recur for at least three months off of treatment, the disease is said to be of limited duration.
  • The episode may be a single episode, or may be recurrent, with symptoms and signs recurring after at least three months of absence of inflammation off of all therapy.
  • This is in contrast to chronic disease, where inflammation (with or without symptoms) recurs when medication is tapered and stopped.

Aetiology:

  • AAU may occur as an isolated medical problem without any association with illness or inflammation elsewhere in the body.
  • It might also arise as part of a localized infection such as that due to the virus that causes cold sores, herpes simplex.
  • It can occur rarely as an adverse reaction to a medication. AAU may also be associated with an illness affecting multiple parts of the body.
  • The most common illnesses associated with AAU are also associated with a genotype known as HLA-B27.
  • A detailed explanation of HLA-B27 and those diseases associated with HLA-B27 is found elsewhere on this website, but the most common association with AAU is ankylosing spondylitis, an inflammatory arthritis associated with HLA B27.
  • Most diseases of other organs that are linked to AAU are apparent from associated symptoms. For example, bowel inflammation or colitis can be associated with AAU.
  • A patient who has this association would usually have abdominal problems such as crampy abdominal pain, weight loss, and/or diarrhea.
  • Some of the less common diseases associated with AAU include sarcoidosis, interstitial nephritis (a rare kidney inflammation), relapsing polychondritis (a rare autoimmune disease), and vasculitis (an inflammation of the blood vessel wall).

Reference: Shields 6/e, p. 160-190

questions.text: What is the most frequent site of involvement when leprosy affects the upper respiratory tract?
questions.solution:
The nose is by far the most frequently involved site. Mycobacterium leprae prefers an ambient temperature of less than 37°C.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 30 Etiology of Infectious Diseases of the Upper Respiratory Tract page no 646

questions.text: A 50-year-old insulin-dependent diabetic patient presents with unilateral purulent rhinorrhoea and proptosis. Physical examination shows ulceration and necrosis of the lateral nasal wall. Appropriate treatment of the most likely diagnosis includes
questions.solution:
• Treatment of Mucormycosis requires a prolonged course of amphotericin B, as well as aggressive surgical debridement of all nonviable tissue.
  • Antifungal azoles are ineffective. The underlying condition must be corrected if possible.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 30 Etiology of Infectious Diseases of the Upper Respiratory Tract page no 648

questions.text: A central molecule in allergic disease is IgE, which interacts with
questions.solution:
• Immunoglobulin E plays a critical role in the immune response.
  • This begins when macrophages and other antigen presenting cells process the allergen before presenting it to T helper cells, which then interact with B lymphocytes, leading to their differentiation into IgE-producing plasma cells, a process involving interleukin-4, interleukin-13, and accessory molecules such as CD40.
  • These newly formed IgE molecules bind to high-affinity receptors principally located on mast cells and basophils and to low-affinity receptors located on eosinophils, monocytes, and platelets.
  • The high-affinity IgE receptors on mast cells mediate the immediate allergic response. Although the mast cell is perhaps a central player with IgE, the presence of receptors on a number of immune cells is in agreement with a view of the allergic response as a complex, coordinated effort of a number of players (cells, chemokines, adhesion molecules, reflexes, etc).

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 32 Allergic Rhinitis page no 710

choices.text: Removing all of the sinus mucosa.

questions.text: The goals of endoscopic sinus surgery include all of the following except
questions.solution:
• In functional endoscopic sinus surgery, it is critical to preserve as much normal mucosa as technically feasible.
  • Removal of mucosa prolongs the healing process and leads to scarring with abnormal, poorly functioning mucosa.
  • The other choices represent key principles of functional endoscopic sinus surgery.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 34 Sinusitis and Polyposis page no 774

questions.text: The histology of malignant tumours of the sinonasal tract is varied; the type with the most well-known link to environmental exposure to wood dust is
questions.solution:
Exposure to wood dust increases the relative risk of adenocarcinoma by 540 times. However, it should be noted that squamous cell carcinoma also shares this relationship to wood dust, with prolonged exposure resulting in 21 times increase in relative risk.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 36 Neoplasms of the Nose and Paranasal Sinuses page no 808

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common complication of adenotonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
• All are complications of adenotonsillectomy, but nasopharyngeal stenosis is the least common.
  • Postoperative bleeding is the most serious complication, occurring in up to 3% of patients. Dehydration is common, especially with children, because they will not swallow because of the severe throat pain.
  • Hypernasal speech commonly occurs immediately following the operation because the pain limits motion of the tonsillar pillars and soft palate.
  • This usually resolves in several weeks.
  • Torticollis is not uncommon and is usually caused by inflammation of the paraspinus muscles.
  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis is rare and develops when the inferolateral adenoid tissue is removed and there is simultaneous denuding or excision of the posterior tonsillar pillars.
  • Adhesions form between the raw surfaces, resulting in scarring and obstruction.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 44 Diseases of the Oral Cavity, Oropharynx, and Nasopharynx page no 1034

questions.text: A patient with human immunodeficiency virus with a CD4 counts of less than 200 cells/mm3 presents with a polyp of the middle ear and discharge. These findings are most likely attributable to an infection that would respond best to which treatment?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystis carinii infections of the middle ear respond well to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 30 Etiology of Infectious Diseases of the Upper Respiratory Tract page no 641

questions.text: After incubation with the chemotherapy drug and cell detachment from the tissue culture plate, the DNA is harvested from the cells and run on a gel. Of note, there are large bands at every multiple of 180 base pairs on the gel. Which of the following explains this finding?
questions.solution:
DNA cleavage products found in multiples of 180 base pairs are characteristic of apoptosis, which is mediated by caspase activation.

  • Apoptosis is programmed cell death that occurs via 2 pathways: an intrinsic pathway and an extrinsic pathway.
  • Both pathways involve the activation of cytosolic caspases, which then mediate cell breakdown.
  • As a part of apoptosis, karyorrhexis refers to fragmentation of the nucleus.
  • During this process, endonucleases cleave DNA at inter-nucleosomal linker sites, which results in segments that occur in multiples of 180 base pairs, since each nucleosome spans an interval of approximately 180 base pairs.

Other Options:

  • Option A: ATP depletion occurs in the setting of ischemia, which would result in tissue necrosis. Apoptosis is a process that requires ATP.
  • Option C: Cellular swelling is seen in necrosis as the plasma membrane becomes permeable due to damage to the phospholipid bilayer. Cell shrinkage is seen in apoptosis.
  • Option D: Protein denaturation can occur in several forms of necrosis and is not directly involved in the nucleic acid cleavage seen in apoptosis.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31

choices.text: Release of vascular endothelial growth factor

questions.text: MRI brain of a HSV Encephalitis patient shows edema and areas of haemorrhage in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism of the development of edema?
questions.solution:
• Breakdown of endothelial tight junctions causing damage to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is the pathologic mechanism underlying vasogenic edema.
  • Disruption of the BBB leads to extravasation of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space of the cerebral parenchyma, leading to increased intracranial pressure and neuronal dysfunction.
  • This mechanism of edema development can also be due to other inflammatory conditions, metastasis, trauma, or lead poisoning.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Release of vascular endothelial growth factor is one of the pathologic mechanisms of edema in brain tumors.
  • Option B: Cellular retention of sodium leading to fluid retention and cellular swelling is the pathologic mechanism of cytotoxic edema,
  • Option C: Degranulation of eosinophils is part of the pathologic mechanism of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31

questions.text:
A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on liver biopsy is shown. These biopsy findings are most characteristic of which of the following types of inflammatory reactions?
HbSAg: POSITIVE
AST & ALT: ELEVATED
questions.solution:
• The patient's biopsy shows signs of tissue destruction and repair, with piecemeal necrosis and ground glass hepatocytes.
  • Together with the serum studies positive for Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), elevated AST/ALT suggests viral hepatitis.
  • The patient's biopsy shows lymphocytic infiltrates, piecemeal necrosis, and ground glass hepatocytes, which are typical of chronic viral hepatitis.
  • Chronic inflammation of any tissue typically shows mononuclear cell infiltration (e.g., lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages) and fibrosis may be present simultaneously as well.

Other Options:

  • Option A: While this patient's serum findings, including the presence of HBsAg and elevated transaminases, could be seen in acute viral hepatitis, this patient's liver biopsy lacks key features such as eosinophilic single-cell necrosis (Councilman body), stellate cells, and diffuse apoptosis. The piecemeal necrosis seen here is not consistent with acute inflammation.
  • Option B: Ischemic necrosis on liver biopsy is commonly seen in patients presenting with acute hepatitis and would appear as necrotic hepatocytes around the central venules. This patient's biopsy, however, shows piecemeal necrosis, which is not consistent with ischemic necrosis. Furthermore, serum studies are suggestive of viral hepatitis.
  • Option C: Malignant transformation (e.g., development of hepatocellular carcinoma) may occur as a consequence of hepatitis B infection, which this patient has. However, expected biopsy findings would include signs of nuclear atypia or dedifferentiation, which are not present here.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 57

choices.text: A spongiform cortex with large intracellular vacuoles

questions.text: A 71-year-old female with worsening memory, behaviour changes, and disorientation over the span of several years, passes away due to severe pneumonia. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on autopsy?
questions.solution:
• The patient in this vignette most likely has Alzheimer's dementia. The classic histological finding in this condition is extracellular amyloid forming parenchymal plaques.
  • The histology of Alzheimer's disease involves senile/neuritic plaques composed of an extracellular Aß-amyloid core derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP).
  • APP is normally degraded via alpha-cleavage; however, when ß-cleavage of APP occurs, it can result in the accumulation of Aß-amyloid.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are also present in Alzheimer's disease; they are composed of intracellular aggregations of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Lewy bodies are seen in Parkinson's disease, not Alzheimer's disease. The patient has no signs of a movement disorder.
  • Option C: Pick bodies are characteristic of Pick's disease, not Alzheimer's disease. Pick would present similarly but more personality changes and is less common than Alzheimer's disease
  • Option D: A spongiform cortex with large intracellular vacuoles is characteristic of Creutzfeld-Jakob disease, not Alzheimer's disease. This condition would have a much more rapid onset.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 182

questions.text: Which of the following properties is most likely responsible for the ability of these neoplastic cells to metastasize?
questions.solution:
• Not all cancers are capable of metastasis.
  • Invasive neoplastic lesions possess specific properties that enable them to invade cell basement membranes and propagate through adjacent tissues and structures.
  • Overproduction of proteases such as collagenase and matrix metalloproteinases are essential to facilitating cancer metastasis.
  • These enzymes cleave components of the basement membrane and interstitium, such as collagen IV.
  • As a result, tumor cells are exposed to growth factors that promote angiogenesis and chemotaxis.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Loss of cellular polarity is a hallmark of dysplastic tissue that enables asymmetric cell division, inactivates tumor suppressor proteins, and reduces pro-apoptotic signalling. The consequences of disordered cellular polarity permit tumor survival but it is not thought to be a crucial aspect of metastasis.
  • Option B: E-cadherin plays an important role in cellular adhesion and acts to oppose the metastatic process. Tumors with extensive metastatic potential would, therefore, be expected to demonstrate downregulated or inactivated E-cadherin.
  • Option C: A high N:C ratio is a feature of neoplastic cell pleomorphism and is associated with poorly differentiated tumors and an increased likelihood of metastasis. Despite the possible prognostic value of the N:C ratio, it is not part of the metastatic mechanism.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 189

choices.text: Skin infections with absent pus formation, delayed umbilicus separation
Cardiac defects, hypoparathyroidism, palatal defects, and learning disabilities
Chronic diarrhoea, oral candidiasis, severe infections since birth, absent thymic shadow

questions.text: Which of the following would be expected in an infant with defective LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein on phagocytes, in addition to recurrent bacterial infections?
questions.solution:
• Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD) type 1 is an autosomal recessive defect in LFA-1 (CD-18) leading to loss of integrin on phagocytes, predisposing patients to recurrent bacterial infections, absent pus formation, and classically, delayed separation of the umbilicus at birth.
  • A defect in integrin formation means that neutrophils traveling in the bloodstream are unable to exit at sites of infection, leading to the clinical presentation described. Biopsy of infected skin sites shows absence of neutrophils.
  • LAD type 1 is treated with prophylactic antibiotics and bone marrow transplant for those with especially severe cases.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked immunodficiency characterized by thrombocytopenia at birth and eczema by one year.
  • Option C: DiGeorge syndrome is a deletion on chromosome 22 leading to immunodeficiency, and potential cardiac defects, hypoparathyroidism and cleft plate.
  • Option D: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) results from many different genetic mutations including in adenosine deaminase and results in near-complete lack of B- and T-cell function.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 168

choices.text: Linear aggregations of red blood cells
Leucocytosis with abundant mature myeloid cells

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents with a 7-month history of fatigue and low back pain. Laboratory analysis is notable for a calcium of 11.5 mg/dL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, and BUN is 30 mg/dL. Large eosinophilic casts are seen on renal biopsy. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis in this patient is multiple myeloma, which is characterized by excess immunoglobulin production.
  • The increased plasma protein concentration in multiple myeloma predisposes red blood cells (RBCs) to form linear stacks (rouleaux) which are visible on peripheral blood smear.
  • The differential diagnosis for chronic fatigue and bone pain in an elderly individual includes underlying malignancy, systemic rheumatologic disease, and endocrine disorders.
  • These symptoms, in combination with laboratory findings notable for hypercalcemia and renal failure, should narrow the differential diagnosis to multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is a monoclonal plasma cell malignancy associated with excess immunoglobulin production.
  • Symptoms of multiple myeloma are either caused by destruction of the bone and bone marrow by plasma cell proliferation or by deposition of immunoglobulins in various tissues.
  • Anaemia with a low reticulocyte count is a common laboratory finding in addition to hypercalcemia and signs of renal failure (elevated creatinine and elevated blood urea nitrogen).
  • Urine analysis may show large eosinophilic casts composed free immunoglobulin light chains that deposit in the renal tubules (Bence-Jones proteins).
  • Peripheral blood smear may show rouleaux because the increased plasma protein concentration facilitates the aggregation of RBCs.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Reticulocytes are immature RBCs. Increased numbers of reticulocytes are seen in various causes of anemia in order to replace lost RBCs. However, in the setting of multiple myeloma, the bone marrow is infiltrated by neoplastic plasma cells, thereby limiting the ability of the bone marrow to produce reticulocytes.
  • Option C: Schistocytes are fragmented, irregularly shaped RBCs that arise in microangiopathic diseases such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) and macroangiopathic mechanisms such as artificial heart values or other intravascular implants.
  • Option D: Abundant granulocytes and cells of the myeloid lineage are seen in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). CML is often asymptomatic but can present with malaise, weight loss, fever, chills, and night sweats.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

questions.text: A 56-year-old man has fatigue, episodic pruritus, and headaches. A CBC reveals a hematocrit of 59% with no other abnormalities. A peripheral blood smear is shown in the image. Mutation in which of the following genes is responsible for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient presents with symptoms and laboratory evidence suggestive of polycythaemia vera (PV), which is most commonly caused by mutation in the JAK2 gene.
  • PV is one of the myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) including essential thrombocytosis (ET), chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML), and primary myelofibrosis as the main disease entities.
  • Mutations in the tyrosine kinase Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2) are found in nearly all patients with PV and roughly 60 percent of patients with ET and primary myelofibrosis.
  • The most common mutation in JAK2 found in PV patients is V617F.
  • Image shows the peripheral blood smear of a patient with PV. It shows an abundance of red blood cells, with no abnormalities in WBC or platelet lineages.

Other Options:

  • Option A: BCR-ABL is the fusion protein responsible for disease proliferation in CML. It is the molecular target of the drug imatinib.
  • Option B: The RET proto-oncogene is mutated in the MEN syndromes, not in PV.
  • Option C: p53, a tumor-suppressor gene, is nonspecifically mutated in numerous malignancies. It is not the principal mutation found in PV.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Green birefringence on Congo red staining
Mesangial expansion and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis
Thickening and hyperplastic sclerosis of arteriolar walls

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents for fatigue and constipation for the past 2 weeks. USG shows enlarged kidneys. Urine dipstick shows 3+ protein. X-ray skull is shown. What histopathological findings of the kidneys would you expect to find?
questions.solution:
• This patient's age, proteinuria, constipation and increased lucencies of the skull suggest a diagnosis of multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma can lead to primary amyloidosis of the kidneys, as seen in this patient. Histological findings of amyloidosis include apple-green birefringence with Congo red staining.
  • Primary amyloidosis is due to the deposition of Ig light chain proteins, which is overproduced in plasma cell disorders or multiple myeloma.
  • It often affects multiple organ systems: cardiac (restrictive cardiomyopathy and arrhythmia), hematologic (splenomegaly and easy bruising), GI (hepatomegaly), and neurologic (neuropathy), with the renal system being the most common. Ig light chain fibrils are deposited at the mesangium, which is responsible for producing the apple-green birefringence under polarized light when stained with Congo red.

Other Options:

  • Option B: Mesangial expansion and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis, or otherwise known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, are seen in diabetic glomerulonephropathy. This patient has no history of diabetes and thus this condition is less likely.
  • Option C: Normal findings can be seen in minimal change disease, which is a type of nephrotic syndrome that most commonly occurs in children or in adults with lymphoma. This patient's history of multiple myeloma is more suggestive of amyloidosis.
  • Option D: Thickening and hyperplastic sclerosis of arteriolar walls are seen in hypertensive nephrosclerosis, which is a likely condition given this patient's hypertension. However, kidneys are often smaller in size and not enlarged in hypertensive nephropathy. This patient's enlarged kidneys are more in line with amyloidosis.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Increased PT and PTT, decreased platelets and fibrinogen, smear from Figure A
Increased PT and PTT, increased platelets and fibrinogen, smear from Figure A
Increased PT and PTT, increased platelets and fibrinogen, smear from Figure B
Decreased PT and PTT, decreased platelets and fibrinogen, smear from Figure B

questions.text:
A 61-year-old male was found to be septic and was oozing from his intravenous catheter site. He also develops petechiae on his shoulders and abdomen. Which of the following test results and blood smears is consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation?

Figure A.

Figure B.
questions.solution:
• This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which presents with an increased PT and PTT, decreased platelets and fibrinogen, and schistocytes on peripheral blood smear (Figure A).
  • DIC is a consumptive coagulopathy that most often occurs in the setting of sepsis, neoplasms, or trauma.
  • Common symptoms and signs include bleeding from venepuncture sites, haematuria, and petechiae.
  • Treatment includes administration of fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors, as well as cryoprecipitate and platelets.
  • Patients often need large amounts of blood products, as administered products are often consumed as part of the ongoing DIC process.
  • There is an increased risk of both bleeding and clotting, and the risk of mortality is high.
  • Figure A shows a blood smear with both normal red blood cells and schistocytes. Figure B shows a blood smear with normal red blood cells, a lymphocyte (large cell on the left), and a neutrophil (large cell on the right).

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase and CD10 positive

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with fatigue and weight lossLymph node exam is notable for symmetrically enlarged axillary lymph nodes bilaterally. On his labs, his hemoglobin is 12.0 g/dL, and his leukocyte count is 24,000/mm^3. A peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is likely characteristic of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
• This elderly patient with weight loss, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and leucocytosis with a blood smear demonstrating smudge cells likely has chronic lymphocytic leukaemia, which is often a CD5 and CD20 positive B-cell neoplasm.
  • Leukaemia's are blood neoplasms that involve unregulated white blood cell proliferation, leading to decreased production of other cell lines such as red blood cells and platelets.
  • In chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), B-cell lymphocytes build up in the bone marrow, lymph nodes, and blood, which leads to poor white cell functioning and increased infections.
  • In CLL, a peripheral blood smear demonstrates damaged cells known as smudge cells, which are due to the fragility of cancer cells in the process of preparing them onto a glass slide.
  • When CLL proliferates in the lymph nodes without cancer cells found in the blood, this is known as small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL).
  • CLL is positive for CD5 and CD20. CD20 is a surface antigen present on B-cells beginning at the pro-B phase.
  • While CD5 is typically a T-cell marker, it is found in B-cell malignancies of both CLL and mantle cell lymphoma.
  • Image shows PBS with an arrow demonstrating a smudge cell.
  • These smudge cells are formed when fragile cancer cells rupture during the process of making the blood smear.

Other Options:

  • Option A: CD15 and CD30 positive cells are Reed-Sternberg cells that are found in Hodgkin disease. These appear as binucleate owl eyes. The smudge cells shown on this smear are not characteristic of this disease.
  • Option C: An M spike on serum protein electrophoresis is characteristic of excess myeloma protein produced in multiple myeloma. This patient does not demonstrate plasma cells or rouleaux formation on the smear, which may be found in multiple myeloma.
  • Option D: Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) positive staining is seen in hairy cell leukemia. This is a B-cell tumor in elderly adults where cells have hairy projections seen on blood smear.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Bacteraemia secondary to a recent dental procedure
Aberrant flow causing platelet-fibrin thrombus formation secondary to hypercoagulability and malignancy
Bacteraemia secondary to a urinary tract infection
Immune complex deposition and subsequent inflammation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with fevers, fatigue, weight loss, joint pains, night sweats and a rash on the bridge of her nose. What would be the most likely pathogenetic cause of cardiac lesion?
questions.solution:
• This patient's signs and symptoms point to a diagnosis of SLE. Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a sterile/inflammatory endocarditis that is commonly associated finding with SLE.
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis (LSE) is a type of endocarditis that is not caused by bacteria.
  • It is one of the most common cardiac findings associated with lupus, occurring in up to 25% of SLE patients.
  • The mitral valve is most commonly affected, with small vegetations appearing on both sides of the valve. These vegetations can cause mitral valve leaflet thickening; however, this is usually an asymptomatic process.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Subacute bacterial endocarditis would not be expected in a patient with lupus without other incriminating historical data.
  • Option B: Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis, also known as marantic endocarditis, is a paraneoplastic syndrome seen most often with primary GI cancers. These may cause emboli to the periphery.
  • Option C: Acute bacterial endocarditis is usually caused by S. aureus in IV drug abusers.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 399

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure on arrival is 70/50 mmHg and his heart rate is 130 bpm. During hospitalization, he developed oliguria. He is eventually discharged with restored renal function. Which of the following was responsible?
questions.solution:
• This patient's renal failure was due to ischemic acute tubular necrosis, secondary to hypovolemia.
  • Acute tubular necrosis classically results in oliguria, 'muddy brown'pigmented renal tubular cell casts as seen in Figure, hyperkalaemia, and anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) may be ischemic (due to hypovolemia in this case) or toxic (for example due to aminoglycosides, CT contrast, or ethylene glycol).
  • It proceeds through an oliguric phase where GFR drops and creatinine rises, followed by a diuretic phase that subsides with tubular re-epithelization and regain of renal function. Treatment is largely supportive, with an immediate goal being repleting volume status, and patient should be monitored for indications for dialysis.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Pyelonephritis would present with fever, costovertebral angle tenderness and positive urine leukocyte esterase and nitrites.
  • Option B: Diabetic glomerulopathy is a progressive renal disease due to diabetes leading to glomerulosclerosis and proteinuria, hypertension and edema.
  • Option C: Glomerulonephritis may be post-infectious and produce hematuria or proteinuria and hypertension.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 549

questions.text: Endoscopic biopsy taken from a segment of the oesophagus is shown in image. Which of the following is a concern associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
• This patient with cough and regurgitation consistent with a history of GERD and glandular metaplasia of the oesophagus has Barrett oesophagus, which is associated with oesophageal adenocarcinoma.
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease occurs due to a decrease in the tone of the lower oesophageal sphincter.
  • As a result, gastric contents may enter the oesophagus, leading to heartburn and regurgitation that is exacerbated with lying down. GERD may also present as a chronic cough.
  • GERD may lead to a variety of sequelae, including Barrett oesophagus.
  • In Barrett oesophagus, glandular metaplasia occurs in the distal oesophagus wherein the nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium is replaced with columnar intestinal cells with goblet cells.
  • Barrett oesophagus is associated with an increased risk of oesophageal adenocarcinoma.
  • Treatment of Barrett oesophagus includes management of GERD with PPIs and lifestyle changes such as elevating the head of the bed. Surveillance with endoscopy may be necessary to screen for malignancy.

Other Options:

  • Option B: Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma is associated with smoking and alcohol as risk factors; however, this patient's histology is not concerning for squamous cell carcinoma. Smoking is also associated with adenocarcinoma.
  • Option C: Gastric adenocarcinoma is associated with chronic Helicobacter pylori infection. H. pylori infection can result in intestinal metaplasia of the stomach, but this patient has intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus.
  • Option D: Iron deficiency anemia can be related to any form of chronic blood loss, which can be caused by gastrointestinal losses. Plummer Vinson syndrome involves a triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. Patients with Plummer Vinson syndrome have a higher risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 583

questions.text: A 39-year-old male presents with slight hepatomegaly. He drinks 7-8 beers daily. A biopsy of the liver is shown. What is the primary mechanism for this abnormality?
questions.solution:
• Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) plays a key role in fatty acid oxidation and levels of NAD are decreased in the hepatocytes of alcoholics secondary to the metabolism of alcohol.
  • Fat, therefore, accumulates and leads to alcoholic steatohepatitis.
  • One major route for alcohol (ethanol) metabolism is the alcohol dehydrogenase-mediated conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde.
  • In the reaction, NAD is reduced to NADH, therefore cytoplasmic levels of NAD decrease. Eventually, the acetaldehyde formed can be converted to acetic acid in the mitochondria by aldehyde dehydrogenase.

Other Options:

  • Option A: The alcohol dehydrogenase reaction leads to a decrease, not increase, in cytoplasmic NAD levels.
  • Option C: The decrease in cytoplasmic NAD levels lead to a decrease, not increase, in fatty acid oxidation.
  • Option D: In alcoholic steatohepatitis, there is decreased synthesis/exportation of lipoproteins.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 583

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents has a 2-month history of persistent cough with bloody sputum and weight loss. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking and worked in a shipyard during his career. Chest radiography reveals a central mass so a biopsy is obtained with the results shown in image. Which of the following is associated with this patient's most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This male smoker with a central lung mass that is associated with keratin pearls on histology most likely has squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, which can present with hypercalcemia due to release of parathyroid hormone-related protein.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant lung tumor that is heavily associated with male smokers.
  • It presents as a central hilar cavitating lesion that causes cough, haemoptysis, and weight loss similar to other lung cancers.
  • Histologically, squamous cell carcinoma can be distinguished from other lung cancers because it will have prominent keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.
  • An important paraneoplastic manifestation of squamous cell carcinoma is the ectopic release of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP).
  • PTHrP causes hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia similar to the effects of endogenous parathyroid hormone.
  • This cancer can be treated using surgical resection in the early stage and chemotherapy or radiation in the late stage.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Diarrhea can be seen in patients with a carcinoid tumor in the lung. These tumors will be seen as nests of cells and can cause carcinoid syndrome that presents with flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and salivation.
  • Option C Hyponatremia can be seen in patients with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone, which is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with small cell lung cancer; however, this tumor would be seen on histology as small round blue cells.
  • Option D: Myasthenia can be seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome, which is a paraneoplastic manifestation of small cell carcinoma of the lung. This disease would present with muscular weakness that is improved with use. This tumor will be seen on histology as small round blue cells.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 495

questions.text: A patient with Pheochromocytoma's symptoms is produced by cells located in which region of the histology slide shown in figure A?
questions.solution:
• Pheochromocytomas are non-malignant tumor of the adrenal medulla that is derived from chromaffin cells of neural crest origin.
  • This tumor secretes catecholamines in an unregulated manner leading to episodic hypertension, palpitations, and perspiration.
  • Catecholamines can also lead to perspiration and pallor on physical exam. Together, these symptoms can be remembered as the 5 Ps: Pressure, Pain, Perspiration, Palpitations, and Pallor.
  • Catecholamines are normally secreted by cells in the adrenal medulla, which appears on histology as the deepest layer of the adrenal gland with a mixture of chromaffin cells and sympathetic ganglion cells.

Other Options:

  • Option A: A represents the capsule of the adrenal gland. Cells in this region do not secrete any hormones.
  • Option B: B represents the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. Cells in this region will secrete aldosterone but this hormone is not responsible for the symptoms seen in pheochromocytoma.
  • Option C: C represents the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex. Cells in this region will secrete cortisol but this hormone is not responsible for the symptoms seen in pheochromocytoma.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 749

Characteristic feature of Canada -

questions.text: Viral respiratory tract infections can be diagnosed in laboratories by all of the following test except:
questions.solution:
Laboratory diagnosis of viral disease

  • Microscopy: by electron microscope for viral diarrhoea; fluorescent antibody technique ( e.g. rabies) etc.
  • Demonstration of viral antigen: by counterimmuno electrophoresis, Radioimmunoassay, ELISA, precipitation in gel, immunofluorescence.
  • Isolation of virus: by inoculation into animals, eggs or tissue culture.

: as most viruses are heat labile, refrigeration is essential during transport.

Serological diagnosis:

  • By neutralisation, compliment fixation, ELISA, haemagglutination inhibition test, immunofluorescence.
  • It is essential to examine paired sera (acute and convalescent)
  • Serological diagnosis is based on greater than fourfold rise in IgG in convalescent sera when acute and convalescent serum are analysed at the same time. A simultaneous fall in IgM confirms the recent primary viral infection.
  • Paired Sera with rising titres of antibody to Virus specific antigens shift from IgM to IgG are generally accepted as diagnostic of acute viral infection.
  • Hemadsorption and Haemagglutination essay measures the ability of serum antibodies to inhibit RNA virus induced erythrocyte adsorption or agglutination.

Reference: Ananthnarayan edition 9 p 449,457

questions.text: A 30-year-old African male presented with abrupt onset of flu like symptoms, fever, Myalgia and nausea along with vomiting. The resident orders blood test and finds that RFT's and LFT's are Deranged. Bleeding manifestations like bleeding gums, easy bruising end conjunctival injection can be made out. Which family does causative organism belongs to the Electron microscope view of the organism is given below.
questions.solution:
The above symptoms point towards the diagnosis of Ebola fever which is confirmed by the image. Ebola virus belongs to the filoviridae family.

  • Following an incubation period of up to 21 days, presents with abrupt onset of flu like symptoms, diarrhoea/vomiting, high fever, myalgia.
  • Can progress to DIC, diffuse haemorrhage, shock.
  • Diagnosed with RTPCR within 48 hours of symptom onset. Has high mortality rate.
  • Transmission requires direct contact with bodily fluids, formats (including dead bodies), Infected bats or primates.
  • High incidence of nosocomial infection.
  • Treatment includes supportive care,no specific treatment.
  • Vaccination of contacts, strict isolation of infected individuals, and barrier practises for healthcare workers are key to preventing transmission.

Reference: USMLE First Aid, Page 167, page 171.

questions.text: The HACEK group of bacteria includes all of the following except:

  • The HACEK group of bacteria includes
  • Haemophilus species
  • Aggregatibacter species
  • Cardiobacterium hominis
  • EIkenela corrodens
  • Kingela Kingae
  • These organisms are present in the oral cavity as part of the normal respiratory microbiota.
  • EIkenella and Cardiobacterium species have been recovered from the gastrointestinal tract and Female genital tract. They cause infective endocarditis.
  • Haemophilus parainfluenzae is the most common Haemophilus species that is isolated from HACEK endocarditis cases.
  • The species Haemophilus aphrophilus, and Haemophilus paraphrophilus have been combined into a single species, aphrophilus, and placed under the genus Agregatibacter.
  • Haemophilus segnis and Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans have also been added

questions.text: A patient is being operated for exploratory laparotomy. For how many days there will be free gas under diaphragm on erect chest xray?

• The erect chest x-ray (CXR) is the ideal first test for hollow organ perforation and as little as 10-20 mL of free air can be detected under the diaphragm, with the following caveats:
    • About 10 minutes should be left between sitting the patient upright to allow air time to rise; the free air must be sought under the right hemidiaphragm to prevent misinterpretation of the gastric air bubble; and the reviewer must be able to recognise Chilaiditi's syndrome,the harmless and asymptomatic interposition of large bowel between the liver and diaphragm.

questions.text: A 40-year male patient present develop dysphagia to the solid. Patient was taken up for EUS showed first and second sonographic layers with biopsies will reveal eosinophilic granules, tumor stain + for S100. Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A) Fibrovascular polyps are a heterogeneous group of soft tissue tumors most often found in the cervical oesophagus at or near the cricopharyngeus.
  • Option B) Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), lesions typically have regular borders and arise within the first and second sonographic layers. The tumors stain positive for S100, further supporting their origin from Schwann cells. Granular cell tumors are largely benign lesions, with only 1% to 2% having been described as malignant.
  • Option C) Squamous papillomas most often occur in the distal esophagus and are usually associated with some underlying inflammation. They appear as colorless, exophytic projections, with a wart-like projection
  • Option D) Benign submucosal tumors include lipomas, hemangiomas, and neural tumors. Lipomas have a characteristic, homogeneous, hyperechoic, smooth appearance on EUS. Symptoms are rare even with large tumors. Resection is seldom warranted. Hemangiomas typically appear as a purple or reddish nodule. EUS will demonstrate a smooth, hypoechoic, submucosal mass. Most tumors are asymptomatic

questions.text:
A 22-year-old Primigravida at 8th month of gestation came with altered sensorium and delirium. There is h/o persistent vomiting, anorexia and malaise over the past 1 week. There is yellow discoloration of the sclera.
Her BP-100/60 mm of hg, PR-96/min, RR-16/min

questions.text: A criminal convicted for murder is put to investigation by doing his narcoanalysis. He was administered a drug called Scopolamine for the same. By which mechanism does this drug act?

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known as a Selective Oestrogen Receptor Downregulator(SERD)?
questions.solution:
• Fulvestrant is the first FDA approved agent in the new class of drugs that are called selective estrogen-receptor downregulators (SERDs).
  • It has an improved safety profile, faster onset, and longer duration of action than the SERMs due to its pure ER antagonist activity.
  • It was approved for postmenopausal women with hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer that has progressed despite antiestrogen therapy.
  • It binds to the estrogen receptor (ER) with an affinity more than 100 times that of tamoxifen, inhibits its dimerization, and increases its degradation.
  • As a consequence of this ER 'downregulation,' ER-mediated transcription is abolished, completely suppressing the expression of estrogen-dependent genes.
  • Most common adverse effects of this drug include nausea, asthenia, pain, vasodilation (hot flushes), and headache.
  • Bazedoxifene, Ormeloxifene and Ospemifene are SERM's.

questions.text: Indumati was a 47-year-old housewife diagnosed with essential hypertension. She was started on Indapamide and Nifedipine for the same. Her presenting blood pressure was 140/90 mm of Hg. She reports frequent joint pains due to excessive house work and takes Indomethacin at least 2-3 times a week. She is also asthmatic and is on Bambuterol nebulization. She comes for follow-up 2 months later and her BP is 142/88 mm of Hg. She reports that she has been taking her tablets as prescribed. Her physician informs her that her BP is not being controlled with this first line antihypertensive due to a drug Interaction with Indapamide. Which drug in her prescription is implicated in the same?
questions.solution:
• Indomethacin and other NSAIDs diminish the action of high ceiling diuretics by inhibiting PG synthesis in the kidney, through which furosemide and related drugs induce intrarenal haemodynamic changes which secondarily affect salt output.
  • This interference is more marked in cirrhotic and nephrotic patients.
  • Antihypertensive action of thiazides and furosemide is also diminished by NSAIDs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 632

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman, Susan is admitted to the hospital for exacerbation of asthma. During her stay at the hospital, the physician prescribes a drug to improve respiration. The drug works by selectively acting as an agonist at Beta-2 receptor. Which of the following is the most likely adverse effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
• β2 adrenergic agonists are used in pulmonology as bronchodilators, in obstetrics as tocolytic agents, and to manage patients with hyperkalaemia.
  • There are both short-acting and long-acting β2 agonists, and their duration of action determines their clinical application.
  • Their effects are achieved through β2 receptor stimulation.
  • Side effects are partially mediated by the β1 receptor and include anxiety and tremor, as well as life-threatening conditions such as ventricular arrhythmias.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 237

questions.text: A 5-year-old Caucasian boy, Felix, presents with a productive cough that yields thick sputum. His past medical history is significant for three prior pulmonary infections, two of which cultured S. aureus and one that was positive for Pseudomonas. CXR is as follows. Which of the following pharmacologic agents act most directly to counteract the defective physiologic process in these patients?
questions.solution:
• This child has cystic fibrosis (CF), and thus produces viscous mucous as a result of impaired chloride channels (CFTR). N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is a mucolytic that reduces the viscosity of the mucous.
  • N-acetylcysteine's mechanism of action is achieved through the cleavage of disulfide bonds of glycoproteins in the mucus.
  • This helps to loosen the plug and allows the patient to clear the accumulated mucous more easily.
  • NAC is not routinely given CF patients unlike inhaled DNase or hypertonic saline for mucous clearance.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 237

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for recurrent epigastric pain. He reports a 3-month history of epigastric and chest pain that is worse after meals and after lying down. He is prescribed an appropriate medication for his symptoms. However, he returns to clinic 3 months later complaining of decreased libido and enlarged breast tissue. Which of the following medications was this patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
• The patient in this vignette presents with gynecomastia and impotence following initiation of a medication for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This vignette is suggestive of anti-androgenic side effects of cimetidine.
  • Cimetidine is an H2 receptor blocker that indirectly inhibits proton pump function by blocking H2 receptors on parietal and chief cells. H2 receptor blockers such as cimetidine can be used to treat GERD, peptic ulcer disease, and gastritis.
  • However, cimetidine has two important toxicities:

(1) it is a potent inhibitor of P450, and

(2) it can have anti-androgenic side effects such as impotence, decreased libido, and gynecomastia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 695

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, Rajesh comes with a 3-month history of recurrent headaches. The headaches are of a dull, non-pulsating quality. The physician prescribes a drug that irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2 by covalent acetylation. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed by the physician?
questions.solution:
• Aspirin is an irreversible, nonselective inhibitor of both COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes. Inhibition of these enzymes decreases prostacyclin and prostaglandin synthesis, which contributes to aspirin's antipyretic, anti-inflammatory, and analgesic effects.
  • Furthermore, COX-1 inhibition impairs the synthesis of thromboxane A2 in platelets, thereby preventing platelet aggregation.
  • Aspirin may be used for pain management, though its primary medical application is as an antiplatelet agent.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 659

questions.text: A 19-year-old male, Sushant has a history of bipolar disorder. The patient is fatigued and constipated with complaints of feeling cold and has gaining weight. His TSH is elevated, while free T4 and serum T4 have declined. Which of the following is responsible for these abnormalities?
questions.solution:
• The patient's bipolar disorder is being treated with lithium, which can cause hypothyroidism as indicated by the elevated TSH and decreased free and serum T4.
  • Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder.
  • Although the exact mechanism is unknown, it may be related to the inhibition of phosphoinositol recycling in neurons.
  • Lithium is otherwise primarily utilized to prevent and treat acute mania.
  • It has a very narrow therapeutic index; thus, it requires blood monitoring.
  • Side effects of lithium include: hypothyroidism, polyuria, heart-block, sedation, tremor, acne, edema, and leucocytosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 462

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to her oncologist to discuss the chemotherapy options for her newly diagnosed breast cancer. During the meeting, they discuss a drug that inhibits the breakdown of mitotic spindles in cells. Her oncologist explains that this will be more toxic to cancer cells because those cells are dividing more rapidly. Which of the following side effects is associated?
questions.solution:
• This patient with breast cancer who is discussing a drug that prevents breakdown of mitotic spindles is most likely referring to a Taxane, which has the associated side effect of peripheral neuropathy.
  • Taxane such as paclitaxel work by blocking the breakdown of microtubules within cells.
  • This mechanism allows them to hyper-stabilize microtubules in the M phase and prevents the breakdown of mitotic spindles in this phase.
  • Disrupting mitotic spindle activity in turn prevents progression of the cell cycle through anaphase and is toxic to rapidly dividing cells.
  • Taxanes are used in the treatment of ovarian and breast cancer. Important side effects include peripheral neuropathy, myelosuppression, and hypersensitivity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 913

questions.text: A 2.1kg male new-born is delivered at 38 weeks to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following supplements is most important to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition in this new-born?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin K levels are low in all new-borns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant.
  • In addition, new-borns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months.
  • As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal haemorrhagic disease of the new-born.
  • Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the new-born is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 968

questions.text: Immunohistochemical analysis of a biopsy specimen from a breast mass shows malignant cells that stain negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors and positive for human epidermal growth factor receptor 2. The drug that most specifically targets this patient's tumor is also used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Overexpression of HER2 is found in up to 25% of gastric cancers and 15-20% of breast cancers.
  • HER2-positive cancers have been associated with a poor prognosis due to more aggressive tumor growth and higher recurrence rates.
  • However, the introduction of drugs that target HER2, such as trastuzumab, have improved the prognosis.
  • Trastuzumab blocks this receptor, which leads to growth arrest and subsequent apoptosis of cancer cells.

Reference: Gunturu KS, Woo Y, Beaubier N, Remotti HE, Saif MW. Gastric cancer and trastuzumab: first biologic therapy in gastric cancer. Ther Adv Med Oncol. 2013 Mar;5(2):143-51. doi: 10.1177/1758834012469429. PMID: 23450234; PMCID: PMC3556876.

questions.text: How many subjects come under the highlighted blue portion?
questions.solution:
• The median always divides the dataset in half; 50% of patients will be above the median, and 50% of patients will be below the median.
  • The mean, median, and mode are all measures of central tendency.
  • In the case of a normally distributed sample, the mean, the median, and the mode are all equivalent.
  • As the distribution deviates from normality the three measures of central tendency also diverge.
  • The mean is sensitive to the outliers in skewed populations, and as such its ability to describe the central tendency of the distribution is diminished.
  • The median is more commonly employed to describe non-normal distributions as it is constrained by definition to divide the dataset in half. Using this definition, one can quickly determine that of the 250 total patients, 125 must fall below the median.
  • As the blue portion of the curve highlights all observations less than the median, one can conclude that this must include 125 patients.
  • It is important to note that this is true regardless of the shape of the distribution. Even the most widely non-normal distributions will be halved by the median.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: A neurosurgeon is running a clinical trial on deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the nucleus accumbens for the treatment of binge-eating disorder. One of her hypotheses is that DBS is more effective at suppressing binge-eating in non-obese individuals compared to obese individuals. Following their operations, subjects are asked to track daily caloric intake for 6 months in a food diary. Which statistical test would be most appropriate for tackling this question?
questions.solution:
• The t-test is used to compare the means of a continuous variable between 2 groups and determine whether the difference is likely due to chance or some independent variable.
  • Performing a t-test returns a p-value, which is the probability that the null hypothesis is true (the observed difference is due to chance).
  • For most studies, findings are considered statistically significant if p < 0.05. In other words, observed differences are considered genuine if the probability of random chance producing the same results is less than 5%.
  • There are 3 major types of t-tests: one sample, independent samples, and paired sample.
  • One sample t-tests are used to compare the sample mean of a group to a population mean.
  • Independent samples, or unpaired, t-tests are used to compare sample means of 2 independent or uncorrelated groups.
  • Paired sample t-tests are used to compare sample means of two related groups (e.g., same group at different times or conditions).

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: A researcher discovers that one of the staff members who works on Mondays and Thursdays is aware of the study and tells all the patients about how wonderful the new implant is. Which of the following forms of bias does this most likely represent?
questions.solution:
• The fact that patients who are aware of positive expectations surrounding the new implant perform better than those who are unaware of these expectations is most consistent with the Pygmalion effect.
  • Bias is a systematic error in the way that data is collected or analyzed in experiments.
  • Many types of bias exist and all of these forms of bias will introduce nonrandom variation into an experiment such that the results are not reliable.
  • One important form of bias is expectation bias where either the high or low expectations of an investigator are conveyed to study subjects.
  • High expectations can cause subjects to experience positive results such that the expectations become a 'self - fulfilling prophecy.'
  • This effect is known as the Pygmalion effect.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: Rishi and Sunaina are married to each other for 30 years. They have had 2 boys. One of them just got married and settled in another city. Which phase does Rishi & Sunaina's family as well as his married son's family lie in the family life cycle respectively?
questions.solution:
Stages of Family Life cycle:

  1. Formation: at time of marriage
  2. Extension: at the birth of first child
  3. Complete Extension: at the birth of last child
  4. Contraction: marriage of first child and his/her leaving the family
  5. Complete Contraction: marriage of last child and his/her leaving the family
  6. Dissolution: death of one spouse
  7. Extinction: death of another spouse

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 560

questions.text: Which government ministry handles the National Disaster Management Authority?
questions.solution:
• National Disaster Management Authority, abbreviated as NDMA, is an apex Body of Government of India, with a mandate to lay down policies for disaster management.
  • NDMA was established through the Disaster Management Act enacted by the Government of India on 23 December 2005.
  • NDMA is responsible for framing policies, laying down guidelines and best-practices for coordinating with the State Disaster Management Authorities (SDMAs) to ensure a holistic and distributed approach to disaster management.
  • NDMA is handled by the Ministry of Home Affairs, GoI.
  • It is headed by the Prime Minister of India and can have up to nine other members. Since 2020, there have been five other members.
  • There is a provision to have a Vice Chair-person if needed.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 889

questions.text: One of the tables in a study compares the two experimental groups with regard to socioeconomic demographics (e.g., age, income), medical conditions at the time of recruitment, and family history of breast cancer. The purpose of this table is most likely to evaluate which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The two groups should ideally be very similar with regard to baseline characteristics related to socioeconomic demographics, medical conditions, and family history.
  • Randomization is a central component of clinical trials.
  • Unlike other methods of assigning cases and controls (e.g., restriction, matching, or stratified analysis), which rely on the investigator's knowledge of possible confounders, randomization can control for both known and unknown confounders.
  • In order to show that randomization was performed successfully, most clinical studies include a table of patient characteristics that compares the different groups in order to show that possible confounders (socioeconomic status, demographics, etc.) are distributed approximately equally between the two groups.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text:
The given image shows the natural progression of a disease.

What is the time between the first possible point and the final critical point known as?
questions.solution:
• The first possible point of diagnosis is an ideal, whereas the critical point is one which is optimum for the population in terms of accessibility and affordability.
  • Thus, if a test is applied between these two points, it can ensure early diagnosis of the disease. It is known as the screening time.
  • On the other hand, the time between the first possible point and the usual point of diagnosis is the lead time, which is the time gained by early detection of disease.
  • A good screening test has a longer lead time and a shorter screening time.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 150

questions.text: The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan-Gramin targets sustainability in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The targets of Swachh Bharat Abhiyan are-

  • Open defecation free behaviours are sustained and no one is left behind.
  • Solid and liquid waste management facilities are accessible and reinforcing ODF behaviours and focus on providing interventions for safe management of solid and liquid waste in villages
  • To encourage cost effective and appropriate technologies for ecologically safe and sustainable sanitation.
  • To develop, wherever required, community managed sanitation systems focusing on scientific Solid & Liquid Waste Management systems for overall cleanliness in the rural areas.

questions.text: The following logo addresses which public health problem?
questions.solution:
• The Government of India launched the National Mental Health Programme (NMHP) in 1982, keeping in view the heavy burden of mental illness in the community, and the absolute inadequacy of mental health care infrastructure in the country to deal with it.
  • The district Mental Health Program was added to the Program in 1996.
  • The Program was re-strategized in 2003 to include two schemes, viz. Modernization of State Mental Hospitals and Up-gradation of Psychiatric Wings of Medical Colleges/General Hospitals.
  • The Manpower development scheme (Scheme-A & B) became part of the Program in 2009.

3 main components of NMHP -

  1. Treatment of Mentally ill
  2. Rehabilitation
  3. Prevention and promotion of positive mental health.

Objectives -

  1. To ensure the availability and accessibility of minimum mental healthcare for all in the foreseeable future;
  2. To encourage the application of mental health knowledge in general healthcare and in social development;
  3. To promote community participation in the mental health service development; and
  4. To enhance human resource in mental health sub-specialties.

Strategies -

  1. Integration mental health with primary health care through the NMHP
  2. Provision of tertiary care institutions for treatment of mental disorders
  3. Eradicating stigmatization of mentally ill patients and protecting their rights through regulatory institutions like the Central Mental Health Authority, and State Mental health Authority.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 464

choices.text: The mean will increase; the median will increase; the mode will increase
The mean will stay the same; the median will increase; the mode will increase
The mean will stay the same; the median will increase; the mode will stay the same
The mean will increase; the median will stay the same; the mode will stay the same

questions.text: The mean, median, and mode weight of 37 newborns in a hospital nursery is 3.2kg. In fact, there are 7 infants in the nursery that weigh exactly 3.2kg. The standard deviation of the weights is 1.5kg. The weights follow a normal distribution. A newborn delivered at 5kg is added to the data set. What is most likely to happen to the mean, median, and mode with the addition of this new data point?
questions.solution:
• The addition of an outlier to a large Gaussian data set will move the mean toward the outlier.
  • The mode will not be affected by a single data point. In a case where there are 7 identical data points at the centre of the distribution, the median value will not change with the addition of one outlier.
  • With the addition of a heavier new-born to a normal distribution of new-born weights, the mean will increase and the median and mode will remain the same.
  • In a Gaussian (normal) data distribution, the mean, median, and mode are the same. The mean is the average of the recorded values.
  • The median is the value of the 50th percentile.
  • The mode is the value that appears the most frequently. If an outlier is added to the data set, the mean will be shifted toward the outlier.
  • The median will change with the addition of an outlier only if there are 2 or fewer data points with the value of the median.
  • The value of the outlier will affect the degree to which the mean changes but not the degree to which the median changes.
  • The mode will only change in a data set with a non-normal distribution if the outlier becomes the new mode.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.solution:
• Spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called the receptive field.
  • Sensory Unit: A single afferent neuron with all its receptor endings.
  • Motor unit: Each single motor neuron and the muscle fibres it innervates.
  • Dermatome: Each spinal nerve innervates a segmental field of the skin.

questions.text: The principle that ; In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor; is known as
questions.solution:
• The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell-Magendie law.
  • Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ is stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
  • Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor.
  • Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
  • Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.

Reference: Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology, 26th Edition Page no 161
